loans.name: Maimina's Group

texts.en:
Maimina N. has a food store and wants a loan to build a cabana to increase her sales space. She also wants to add tomatoes and onions to her product selection.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To build a cabana for her store

loans.name: Prossy's Group

texts.en:
Prossy G. sells milk from her shop. She wishes to add an awning to the shop and buy more milk to sell.

loans.name: Mildred's Group

texts.en:
Mildred N. sells soda and beer from her shop. She wants a loan to buy another fridge and to purchase more stock for her shop.

texts.en:
Esther N. sells clothing. She wants the loan to increase her inventory of clothes.

Fatuma I., age 37, is married with a girl (age 15) and a boy (age 6). She owns a cafe, which she started in 1996. Her cafe is open from 6am until 5pm daily, and she earns about $88 a month from this business.

Fatuma has taken a previous loan of about $88 from BRAC Tanzania to buy food stock for her cafe. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup member Sophia T., who owns a general store.

loans.name: Ushirika A Group

texts.en:
Marry J., age 36, is married with one 9-year-old boy. She owns two businesses- a cafe and a business selling soap. She began these businesses in 2006 and now she makes about $106 in profit monthly. Her businesses operate from 4pm to 8pm daily.

In the past, Marry took out an $88 loan from BRAC Tanzania which she was able to pay back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to buy more stock for her businesses. She will be sharing this loan with her subgroup member Ester L., who is also a food seller.

loans.use: To purchase more food stock for her cafe and to also increase her soap inventory

loans.name: Uchumi A Group

texts.en:
Bibiana, age 45, is married with 4 children (ages 17, 21, 28, and 31). She also takes care of her parents. In 2005, Bibiana opened two businesses- a cafe and clothing store. She works at these businesses from 8am to 6pm daily earning a profit of about $53 a month.

In the past, Bibiana took a loan of about $88 from BRAC Tanzania to buy stock for her businesses. Having paid it back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will be sharing this loan with her subgroup member Yusta H., who is a vegetable seller. They belong to the loan group Uchumi (Swahili for "economy"), which totals 25 members.

loans.use: To purchase more food and clothing stock for her businesses

texts.en: Gulasmar (her husband is pictured) was born in 1964. She is a mother of 3 children. The Zeynalov's family lives in Khachmaz region. They have been in this business for 15 years. Now they need a loan of $725 to buy one cattle to fatten for sale.
Namatulla was born in 1980. He is married, has 2 children. Two years ago he started farming business.This man needs a loan of $725 to buy fertilizer for improving his business.

Fakhraddin has been in this business for 3 years. He buys beer from the Guba region and transports to the Khachmaz region in Azerbaijan for sale. He is married and has 3 children. Fakhraddin lives in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan, with his family. He needs a loan of $725 to buy beer to increase his inventory.

Tamam (her husband is pictured) was born in 1967. She is the mother of 2 children. Her husband has been as a taxi driver for 5 years. Tamam and her family live in the  Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Now Tamam needs a loan of $725 to buy spare parts for her family's taxi to  improve their business. 

Note: Tamam's husband is pictured as Tamam did not want to be photographed for cultural reasons.

Gulovsar was born in 1951 and is married with 4 children. Gulovsar has been raising and selling sheep for the past 8 years. He buys young sheep and fattens them before selling. He is requesting a loan of $725 to buy additional sheep to increase his inventory and improve his business sales.

Almanisa is 43 years old and single. She lives in Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Five years ago she started breeding cattle as a business. Now she needs a loan of $725 to buy an additional cow to increase her business opportunities.

Vusala (her husband is pictured) is 28 years old, married, and has 2 children. She lives with her family in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Vusala has been in this farming for 4 years. Now she needs a loan of $725 to buy fertilizer for improving her farm. 

Note: Vusala's husband is pictured as Vusala did not want her picture taken for cultural reasons.

Raya is 24 years old and is the mother of 2 children. She lives with her husband (pictured) and children in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. She has been in farming business for 7 years.  Raya currently  needs a loan of $725 to buy seedlings and pesticides.

Note: Raya's husband is pictured, as Raya did not want to be have her photo taken for cultural reasons.

loans.name: Tapdig

texts.en: Tapdig S. was born in 1952. Tapdig has sold hazelnuts for 5 years. Tapdig is married and has 3 children. He lives with his family in the Khachmaz region. Now Tapdig needs a loan of $725 to buy goods for improving his business and increasing his inventory.

loans.use: To buy hazelnuts to increase inventory

texts.es:
Karla is 29 years old. She is a single mother with 2 sons, both still minors. Three years ago, looking for alternative ways to support her family, she decided to open a small business. She has worked hard to be able to cover her responsibilities as a mother. In her business she sells a variety of products, including clothes, shoes, cell phone cards, etc. The school year will be starting in Nicaragua in a few months and so Karla wants to buy school supplies so that she can distribute them to all the students that visit her store. Her strongest desire is to grow her business in orde to give her children a better life and feel fulfilled as a hard working woman and as a mother.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Karla M. tiene 29 años, es madre soltera, con 2 hijas menores de edad. Hace tres años en busca de alternativas para sustentar a su familia optó por poner un pequeño negocio, con el que ha ido trabajando muy duro para poder cubrir la responsabilidad de ser mamá. En su negocio vende diferentes productos como ropa, zapatos, tarjetas celulares, etc. El año escolar está a poco meses de abrirse en Nicaragua es por eso que Karla quiere comprar útiles escolares para pode ditribuirlos a todos los estudaintes que visitan su pulpería. Lo que más desea es hacer crecer su negocio para darles una mejor vida a sus pequeñas y sentirse realizada como mujer trabajadora y también como madre.

loans.name: José

texts.es:
José M. is a native of the city of León in Nicaragua. He emigrated to Managua in search of a better life and established himself in the neighborhood known as 3-80, a very poor neighborhood in need of road and sewage infrastructure. José is 50 year old and married with 3 children. To be able to feed his family and give an education to his children, he started a small business selling basic grains. He has developed his business over time, and now has a general store where he sells everything from basic grains to clothes. He needs the loan to be able to buy school supplies and shoes. This purchase will prepare him for the school season in Nicaragua, and satisfy the demand of this neighbor in the neighborhood 3-80.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

José M. es originario de la Ciudad de León, Nicaragua. En busca de una mejor vida emigró Managua donde se estableció en el barrio 3-80, un barrio muy pobre y necesitado de mucha infraestructura vial y desagüe. Don José tiene 50 años de edad, casado y con tres niños. Empezó con un pequeño negocio de ventas de granos básicos para poder alimentar a su familia y darle educación a sus hijos. Ha venido desarrollandose, siendo ahora una Miscelanea donde vende desde granos básicos hasta ropa. Necesita el crédito para comprar útiles escolares y zapatos para poder recibir la época escolar en Nicaragua, y satisfacer la demanda de todos sus vecinos en el barrio 3-80.

loans.use: Purchase of school supplies and shoes

loans.name: Karla Vanesa

texts.es:
Karla Vanesa is 30 years old and married. She has 3 children, two of school age and one still a baby. She lives in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood in Managua. 15 years go she started her used iron and scrap metal business. The business has grown continually over the years and now includes two iron-selling businesses, one managed by Karla and the other by her husband. She also has 2 vehicles for the distribution of her products. Her 13 year old daughter helps out in one of the businesses while still attending school. Karla feels that her business will grow larger and more prosperous with the passing years. She is requesting a loan with which to buy more iron and to continue distributing her products to her points of sale: hardware/ironmonger shops and the rest of the orders she receives.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Karla Vanesa tiene 30 años de edad, es casada y tiene 3 niños, dos en edad escolar y un bebé. Habitan en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de Managua. Desde hace 15 años empezó el negocio de compra de chatarra y hierro usado. A través de los años ha ido creciendo y hasta la fecha cuenta con 2 negocios de venta de hierro, uno administrado por ella y el otro por su marido. También cuenta con dos vehícluos para la distribución del producto. Su niña de 13 años también la apoya en uno de los negocios al mismo tiempo que asiste a la escuela. Ella siente que su negocio con el pasar de los años se ha hecho más grande y próspero. El crédito lo quiere para comprar más hierro y seguir distribuyendo el hierro a los puestos de venta, ferreterías y demás pedidos que reciben.

loans.use: Purchase of new and used iron for her business

loans.name: Yesenia Aparicia

texts.es:
Yesenia lives in the Campo Bruce neighborhood in Managua, a popular Managua neighborhood. She is 32 years old and married with 2 small children. She was an only daughter; she and her family live with her mother. Her husband is a taxi driver and occasionally helps Yesenia with the business, along with her mother. She has worked in her own small convenience store in her home for 2 years. She wants the loan so that she can buy meat, milk products and basic grains, in order to be able to offer them to her clients, and in this way continue investing in her business so that it develops into a prosperous shop.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Yesenia vive en el barrio Campo Bruce de Managua, un barrio popular de Managua. Tiene 32 años, casada y con 2 pequeños niños. Ella fue hija única y vive con su mamá. Su esposo es taxista y en ocasiones la apoya en el negocio junto con su mamá. Desde hace dos años tiene una pequeña pulpería en su casa de habitación y quiere el crédito para comprar carnes, lácteos y granos básicos para poder ofertarlos a sus clientes; y así seguir inviertiendo en el negocio para llevarlo a ser una pulpería próspera.

loans.use: Purchase of meat, milk products and basic grains

loans.name: Lapmari

texts.en: Lapmari is a 45-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks, food, and drinks, and also household products. She can earn about US$ 20 per week. Her husband, M., has no fixed income so he works with her. She's requesting a loan to expand  her and her husband's business. Lapmari hopes that she can increase her income to provide tuition for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her little "corner grocery store"

loans.name: Sopiyah

texts.en: Sopiyah is 39 years old. She has a little poultry farm. She buys young birds then raises them and sells them. She usually earns about US$ 18 income per month. She requests a loan to buy more birds to raise. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more birds to raise

loans.name: Kartini

texts.en: Kartini is a 41-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks, food and drinks, and also household products. She can earn about US$ 7 per day with a small profit. Her husband, A., has no fixed income so they work together. She's requesting a loan to expand her and her husband's business. Kartini hopes that she can increase her income to provide tuition for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her little "corner grocery store"

loans.name: Upah

texts.en: Upah M. is a 27-year-old who has a small shop where she sells groceries such as snacks, drinks, eggs, etc. Her husband, Rasdi, has no fixed income. She is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan to buy more goods for her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her little shop

loans.name: Sopiyah

texts.en: Sopiyah is a 30-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks, household goods, beverages,  cigarettes, rice and many other things. She can earn about US$ 44.50 per month, due to the amount and variety of goods she has in stock. Sopiyah is requesting a loan to fill her shop. Her husband has no fixed income, so she has to work hard for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her little shop

texts.en:
Sarah K. is requesting a loan to buying more inventory for her general merchandise shop, such as a refrigerator. With this, Sarah hopes to boost and enlarge her business.

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is 38 years old and makes and sells an Indonesian salad called “gado-gado” at her small food stall from 8 A.M. until evening. She also sells other foods like crackers, snacks, and some fruit at the stall. Her husband, A., is a laborer who earns a small income. Isah is a member of MBK and requests a loan so that she can earn more income for her children’s education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her little business selling convenience foods

texts.en:
Teddy K. wants to build a permanent structure for her saloon and is requesting a loan to do so. With the loan, she also wants to increase her inventory by buying wigs and oils.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.name: Ati

texts.en: Ati is 37 years old and has a small grocery store where she sells household necessities such as cooking oil, rice, eggs, etc. Her husband, H., has no fixed income. Ati usually earns about US$ 1.50 per day in profit.  She is a member of MBK and needs a loan to buy more inventory for her store. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Wahidah

texts.en: Wahidah is 28 years old and is married with two children. Selling snacks is Wahidah's business to support her family, and she usually earns about US$ 10 per day. Her husband, A., has no fixed income. Wahidah is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan to expand her little business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business selling snack foods

texts.en:
Juliet K. wants a loan in order to buy larger quantities of improved seeds for maize and sweet potatoes. This will help her to catch up with the season.

loans.name: Nurhasanah

texts.en: Nurhasanah is 25 years old and has a small grocery store which sells rice, snacks, vegetables, etc., and she usually earns about US$ 17 per day. Her husband, M., has no fixed income. Nurhasanah is requesting a loan to buy more goods for her store. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her little "corner grocery store"

texts.en:
With a loan, Aisha M. wants to buy more tomatoes, onions, curry powder, charcoal and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Iti

texts.en: Iti is 28 years old and is married. She has a small shop and sells rice, snacks, beverages,  vegetables, etc., and she usually earns about US$ 17 per day. Her husband, S., sells food and can earn about US$ 5 per day. Iti is requesting a loan to buy some goods to fill the shop. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Sayina N. is requesting a loan in order to buy more charcoal and sugarcane to increase her sales.

texts.es:
Adela's principal economic activity is selling a varierty of fruits. She has had this business for 15 years, and she started it with 500 córdobas from her own savings. She started her business in Masaya and then moved it to León, where she has a fixed stand with a roof in la Terminal Market.

Adela is a married woman with 6 kids. She and her husband fight to help them get ahead through their education. They are now in primary and secondary school. She has benefited from working with Ceprodel for 2 years. They have helped her with financing, having offered her 6 credits that have let her grow her fruit business and the quality of life of her whole family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Su principal actividad económica es la venta de frutas variadas teniendo su negocio desde hace 15 años que dio inicio con un monto de C$500.00 producto de sus propios ahorros. Su negocio de venta de frutas lo inicia en Masaya y posterior se traslada a León ubicando su negocio en el mercado de la Terminal que es un puesto fijo solo con techo.

Adela Martínez es una señora casada con 6 hijos que junto a su esposo luchan para salir con sus hijos adelante en su proceso de estudio en niveles de primaria y secundaria. Ha sido beneficiada desde hace dos años por Ceprodel quien le asistió con financiamiento habiéndoles otorgado 6 créditos de los que le han impactado en un mayor crecimiento de su negocio de frutas habiendo mejorado su nivel de vida y de toda su familia.

texts.en:
Tatyana and her husband and son are from Melitopol, a city in the southern part of Ukraine near the Black Sea. Tatyana has a successful business selling women’s lingerie from a little outdoor kiosk at the busy Central market in Melitopol. She has been in business for about five years. With hard work and the help of loans from Nadiya Ukraine she has been able to grow and develop her business into a profitable enterprise.

Tatyana would like to continue growing her business in the future. She has requested a loan of $1200 to purchase new inventory so that she can meet customer demand and make a good profit.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is a widow who helps support herself with a small business selling fish at a market near the train station in Melitopol, Ukraine. She sells both a marinated type of fish as well as fresh fish. Ludmila is a very experienced entrepreneur having been in business for twelve years. She currently makes about $600 profit in a typical month. Ludmila understands the financial situation of many elderly people in Ukraine and enjoys giving a discount to her older customers. She has two sons. Her youngest lives with her and also helps her with the business. Her oldest son is married. Ludmila is helping him pay to have a natural gas line hooked up to his house.

Ludmila has requested a loan of $800 to give her additional working capital and help purchase new supplies of fish. We are glad for another opportunity to assist Ludmila in operating a successful business and earning a good living.

loans.use: Increase working capital and purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Angela Benita

texts.es:
Ángela Ramírez works selling clothing such as blouses, trousers, shorts, etc. She has had this business for 4 years and started with C$700.00 that she received from lenders.

Ángela is a woman worthy of admiration because she started as a traveling saleswoman with a small basket and later established herself at the Terminal market where she now has a fixed outdoor stall.

Mrs. Ramírez is married and has 4 children and she struggles to provide them with a good education. Two of her children are already in secondary school thanks to her efforts.

We must acknowledge that Ceprodel has granted her financial support for two years which adds up a total of 12 loans that have helped in the expansion of her business. Thanks to these loans she has had increased profits and above all the support she needed to build her humble home.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La dama Ángela Ramírez se dedica a la actividad económica de la venta de ropa tales como blusas, pantalones, shorts, etc. Teniendo 4 años de poseer el negocio que se inició con un monto de C$700.00 producto de prestamos que adquirió de prestamistas.

La señora Ángela es una mujer digna de imitar ya que comenzó como vendedora ambulante con una canasta pequeña para luego establecerse en el mercado la Terminal que es donde tiene un puesto fijo al aire libre.

Hoy en día la señora Ramírez es casada y tiene 4 infantes por los cuales lucha para educarlos habiendo ya alcanzado la meta de que dos de ellos estén en la secundaria.

No podemos obviar que Ceprodel le ha brindado apoyo financiero desde hace dos años habiendo obtenido un total de 12 créditos que le han ayudado en el crecimiento de su negocio generándole mayores utilidades y sobre todo gran apoyo para poder construir su humilde hogar.

loans.use: The purchase of merchandise such as clothing

texts.en:
Lubov is a hard-working entrepreneur from Melitopol, Ukraine. She has a profitable little business selling a variety of personal care products at an outdoor market near the train station in Melitopol. Lubov has been in business for the past twelve years. She sells a range of product brands and is also a licensed distributor of the Oriflame line of products. Lubov and her husband, Victor, have two daughters. One of her daughters is getting married soon and Lubov is planning to use profits from her business to help with wedding expenses.

Lubov has requested a loan of $1000 to help purchase new inventory for her business. She has benefited in the past with financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine and has paid back all previous loans on time. We are happy to have another opportunity to help this dedicated entrepreneur as she works to earn a good living.

texts.es:
The business of selling all kinds of clothing is a hard one to maintain because of the high levels of competition in that market. However, mindful of this fact, Mrs. Maribel del Carmen R. has had this business for 7 years, having started with a capital of $5,000.00 from her personal savings.

She started as a street vendor, offering her wares throughout the city, with the clothes in her arms. Later on she established herself in the market of the Terminal, where she has a fixed stand out in the open, in an area where there is a lot of competition. Before having this business, she used to sell tortillas, and with her profit from their sale she was able to save enough money to switch businesses. Switching to clothing sales allowed her to improve financially and have a better quality of life for her and her family of two children.

All the progress made by this courageous woman is thanks to Ceprodel which has offered her financial support for a year and a half now, having authorized a total of 7 loans which have helped her to increase her business, stocking better quality of clothing. In this way, Mrs. Carmen makes a living with dignity, and supports her two children who are more precious to her than anything else in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio de venta de ropa para de todo tipo es un negocio muy difícil de mantener por el hecho de que hoy en día la competencia se arrecia y cada vez existen nuevos competidores en este mercado. Sin embargo, consiente de esto, la señora Maribel del Carmen Rodríguez tiene 7 años de tener el negocio que lo inició con un monto de C$5.000.00 producto de ahorros que ella tenia.

Inicia como vendedora ambulante viajando por toda la ciudad y la ropa en los brazos, para luego establecerse en el mercado la Terminal en donde tiene un puesto fijo al aire libre, que es un área en donde hay mucha competencia. Antes de tener este negocio vendía tortillas y con el fondo que logró ahorrar cambió de negocio pudiendo superarse económicamente teniendo ahora un mejor nivel de vida para ella y su familia que son dos hijos

Todo este progreso de esta valiente dama se debe gracias a Ceprodel ya que le ha brindado apoyo financiero de hace año y medio atrás habiendo obtenido un total de 7 créditos que le han ayudado en el crecimiento de su negocio el cual lo ha surtido con mejores marcas de ropa y en mejores condiciones de calidad. De esta manera digna se gana la vida la señora Carmen y así mantiene a sus dos hijos que son lo más preciado que ella tiene en la vida.

loans.name: Prossy's Group

texts.en:
Prossy K. wants a loan in order to boost and expand her salon business. In the long run this will, improve her business, increase her sales, and raise profits.

loans.use: To boost and expand her business

texts.en:
Tatyana is an enterprising business owner from Melitopol, Ukraine. She sells sportswear and leather goods at the large Central market in Melitopol. Tatyana has been in business for over ten years. She has a good location at the market for her attractively arranged sales kiosk. Tatyana was one of the original clients to receive a loan from our Melitopol loan office. Since that time she has not only maintained an excellent credit history, she has also enthusiastically informed other market vendors of the financial assistance available through Nadiya Ukraine. Tatyana is married and has one son. Her father is currently living with her and her husband. Tatyana’s goals for her business include being able to send her son to college and being able to afford to better the living standards for her family.

Tatyana has requested a short term loan of $800 to help purchase new inventory for the fall and winter seasons. She’d like to capitalize on the demand for warmer clothing as people get ready for cold weather. This loan will help Tatyana as she works to make a better life for her and her family.

texts.es:
Mrs. G. works selling a variety of fruits. She has had her business for 25 years, having started with a sum of C$1,000.00 from her savings.

In the beginning, Mrs. G. sold in the city of Masaya, but seeking to make better sales, she moved to Leon and established her business in the market of the Terminal, where she manages to obtain a space (which, by the way, is not in very good condition).

Mrs. G. is a hardworking person, married, and has three children. Together with her husband, she works hard to raise and educate their three little ones who are studying in elementary and jr. high school.

For the past two years she has benefited from Ceprodel's help, having received 25 loans, which have directly aided in the expansion of her fruit business and fixing up the stand where she works.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio a que se dedica la señora G. es a la venta de frutas variadas teniendo su negocio desde hace 25 años que dio inicio con un monto de C$1.000.00 producto del ahorro que la señora tenia.

Para iniciar con este negocio la señora G. vendía en la ciudad de Masaya pero por tener mejores ventas se traslada a León ubicándose en el mercado de la Terminal donde logro obtener un tramo o espacio físico que por cierto no presenta buenas condiciones.

La señora G. es una persona muy trabajadora, casada y con 3 hijos que junto a su esposo luchan para salir adelante en su proceso de formación y educación a sus pequeños que estudian en niveles de primaria y secundaria.

Ha sido beneficiada desde hace dos años por Ceprodel quien le asistió con financiamiento habiéndole otorgado 25 créditos de los que le han beneficiado directamente en una ampliación de su negocio de frutas y obteniendo mejores condiciones en el puesto de su trabajo.

loans.name: Pamella's Group

texts.en:
Pamella A. would like a loan to expand her business to sell more fresh food like cassava, Irish potatoes and sweet potatoes.

loans.use: To boost and expand her business

texts.es:
Candida's principal source of income is making and selling food, a business she started 4 years ago with savings of C$1,500. She started selling fried platano and yucca at local schools, then set out making food at home for sale at the Terminal market, the center for sales in the city.

Candida is a single mother of 5 children who struggles every day to ensure that they can continue at school.

Ceprodel approached Candida two years ago and helped her get 13 loans that have allowed her to develop her cooking skills and make new dishes that have sold very well. All this growth is a consequence of Candida's decision to join Ceprodel from which she'll no doubt receive more benefits in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Su principal actividad económica es la elaboración de comidas teniendo su negocio desde hace 4 años que dio inicio con un monto de C$1.500.00 producto del ahorro que la señora Candida tenía. Ella inicia vendiendo en los colegios bolsas de plátanos fritos y bolsas de yucas fritas, después se dedica a la elaboración de comidas que las hace en su casa para luego trasladarla al mercado la Terminal , que es un punto estratégico para las ventas.

Es una señora madre soltera con 5 hijos que lucha todos los días para salir con sus hijos adelante en su proceso de estudio en niveles de primaria y secundaria.

Fue visitada hace dos años por Ceprodel quien le asistió con financiamiento habiéndoles otorgado 13 créditos de los que le han favorecido para poder desarrollar su habilidad de cocina preparando nuevos platillos que los ha vendido muy satisfactoriamente. Todo este crecimiento se debe a la decisión que la señora Candida tomó al haberse asociado con Ceprodel del cual recibirá mas beneficios.

Selling vegetables in the city of Leon is a very important business for the simple reason that every household needs them. Cristina, having 20 years in the vegetable-selling business in Leon started with C$500 that she saved over a long period of time with the idea of investing in this business. She started selling in the Estacion market with small stocks of vegetables before going on to grow, little by little, until she had her own market stall there.

Now she owns a stall with a zinc ceiling, enclosed with mesh, and is one of the largest sellers, all because she decided to invest in her business. It should be noted, too, that Mrs. F. is a single mother with 2 school-age children for whom she struggles to provide a better quality of life and the chance to have professional careers.

Ceprodel has provided Cristina with important financial help for three years with 34 loans, all repaid on time.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La venta de verduras en la ciudad de León es un negocio muy importante por la sencilla razón de que en cada hogar se consumen estos productos. La señora Cristina teniendo 20 años de tener un negocio de verduras en León inició con un capital de C$500.00 que fueron ahorrados por largo tiempo con la idea de invertir en este negocio. Ella inicia vendiendo en el mercado de la Estación con poca cantidad de verduras hasta ir incrementando poco a poco sus productos hasta conseguir un puesto fijo en el mercado.

Hoy en día posee un puesto fijo con techo de zinc y cerrado con malla, siendo una de las mejores vendedoras por haber decidido invertir en su negocio. Es necesario señalar que la señora F. es madre soltera que tiene 2 hijos estudiando en la secundaria por quienes lucha para brindarles un mejor nivel de vida y así puedan profesionalizarse.

Ceprodel le ha brindado un gran apoyo financieramente desde hace tres años con 34 créditos otorgados y pagados en tiempo y forma por lo que hoy en día esta contemplando un avance en el negocio de las verduras.

The case of Mrs. Felipa R. is a great example for many people. She has worked selling wallets and simple clothing among a variety of products. She started her business 6 years ago with a sum of C$200.00 from her savings.

She started with a small basket, as a street vendor. After obtaining a greater volume of merchandise of varied products to offer to her customers, she established her business in the second street of the market of la Terminal, which is a fixed stand out in the open.

She is a single mother with four children, who works very hard to encourage them in their progress of studying elementary and high school.

She has been affiliated with Ceprodel for a year, having gotten 9 loans which have doubtlessly allow her to improve her business and diversify her market including other products of imitation jewelry.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Un gran ejemplo para muchas personas es el caso de la señora Felipa R. el cual por mucho tiempo se ha dedicado a la venta de billeteras, prendas sencillas de vestir entre otros productos variados. Comenzó su negocio desde hace 6 años con un monto de C$200.00 producto del ahorro que la señora tenia.

Ella inicia con una canasta pequeña ambulante y después creció obteniendo mayor cantidad de mercadería de productos variados para ofrecer a su clientela ubicando su negocio en la segunda calle del mercado de la Terminal que es un puesto fijo al aire libre.

Es una señora madre soltera con 4 hijos que lucha todos los días para salir adelante en su proceso de estudios en niveles de primaria y secundaria.

Fue afiliada hace un año en Ceprodel quien le asistió con financiamiento habiéndoles otorgado 9 créditos que sin lugar a duda han podido mejorar su negocio logrando diversificar su mercado con otros productos del mismo ramo de bisuterías.

Mrs. Idalia Victora's business centers on the sale of basic grains such as rice, beans, and corn, which she sells both wholesale and retail. She has had this business for 10 years, having started with a capital of C$2,000.00 which was a contribution from her husband.

Before starting this business, Mrs. Idalia Victoria, being a very responsible other, earned their daily bread doing housework for others, such as washing and ironing clothes. When she realized that this business did not fulfill their needs, she decided to start selling basic grains, managing to secure a fixed stand with a zinc roof. In spite of being a single mother, with 4 children all in elementary school, she has made great efforts to support her family and get ahead given that she is the only source of income in her household.

In spite of Mrs. Idalia position as a mother and a father, Ceprodel has offered her a financial hand for three years now, with nineteen loans given and paid back on time. This has benefited her by allowing her to acquire larger volumes of grains to be able to commercialize them and thus be able to sustain her four children who need her support now more than ever.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio de la señora Idalia Victoria se centra en la venta de granos básicos como arroz, frijoles y maíz, vendidos al por mayor y al detalle. Tiene 10 años de tener el negocio el cual lo inició con un capital de C$2.000.00 obtenido de un aporte de su esposo.

La señora Idalia Victoria antes de iniciar su negocio, por ser una madre muy responsable se ganaba el pan de cada día realizando trabajos de empleo domestico como es el lavado y planchado de ropa. Al darse cuenta que este negocio no abastecía su necesidad, toma la decisión de comenzara a vender los granos básicos logrando alcanzar un puesto fijo con techo de zinc. A pesar de ser madre soltera y con 4 hijos todos estudiando en la primaria ha hecho grandes esfuerzos para salir adelante y poder mantener a su familia debido a que ella es el único sustento en su hogar.

A pesar de la posición de padre y madre de la señora Idalia, Ceprodel le ha brindado la mano financieramente desde hace tres años con diecinueve créditos otorgados y pagados en tiempo y forma lo que le ha ocasionado un beneficio en la adquisición de mayores niveles de granos para poderlos comercializar y así mantener a sus cuatro hijos que hoy mas que nunca necesitan de su apoyo.

Mrs. Julia works selling vegetables such as yuca (cassava), chayotes (a kind of summer squash), tomatoes, cabbage, etc. She has been working on this business for 15 years, having started with a capital of C$500.00 which she had saved with the idea of starting her own business.

Mrs. Julia started selling in the market of la Estacion (the station), with a small volume of sales. Then she moved to the market la Terminal in the second street, which is the produce section. Before having this business, she worked as a cleaning lady, but she decided to change businesses because her income as a maid was not enough to sustain her family, which consists of 3 school-age children.

Ceprodel has given her a hand, financially speaking, during the past three years, with a total of 18 loans, which she has paid in full and in time. With this help she has been able to improve her business, and more importantly, she has been able to offer her children the opportunity to study so that in the future they can be well-prepared and get out of this very difficult financial situation in which they have found themselves.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio al cual se dedica la señora Julia es a la venta de verduras tales como yuca, challotes, tomates, repollos, etc. Tiene 15 años de tener el negocio iniciando con un capital de C$500.00 producto de ahorros propios que ella hacia con la idea de iniciar su digno negocio.

La señora Julia inicia vendiendo en el mercado de la Estación con pocos volúmenes de venta para luego trasladarse al mercado la Terminal en la segunda calle que es el sector de las verduras, antes de este negocio trabajaba como domestica pero decidió cambiar de negocio ya que no le generaba los suficientes ingresos para mantener su familia que consta de 3 hijos todos en etapa escolar.

Ceprodel le ha brindado la mano financieramente desde hace tres años con 18 créditos otorgados y pagados en tiempo y forma por lo que ha mejorado su negocio y sobre todo ha podido brindarle los estudios a sus hijos para que en un futuro puedan ser personas muy preparadas y salir de la difícil situación económica en la que se han encontrado.

texts.en:
Sarah M. is requesting a loan to purchase more seeds for her mushroom business. She would like to expand her business and eventually become a wholesaler and a big supplier to various people.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

texts.es:
Selling tortillas is a very common business in Leon, that’s why Maria B. has been making tortillas since a very young age, she has been dedicated to this craft for 30 years. She started with an investment of C$300.00 from a loan she got locally. Today she is working in the market at the Terminal, most precisely to the East of the intercity arrivals of the bus lines.

Maria has a solid spot with a zinc ceiling in the market and receives most of her help from her grandson. She takes care of this grandson because his parents are not around.

Aware of the Maria B. necessities, Ceprodel has given her financial support for around two and a half years, she has received a total of twenty loans. She has wisely invested this money in the infrastructure of her spot in the market and in the cost required to feed and clothe her little grandson.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

La venta de tortillas es un negocio muy común en la ciudad de León, es por eso que la señora María B. se dedica a elaborar las tortillas desde muy jovencita teniendo 30 años de dedicación constante a esta labor. Inició con un capital de C$300.00 producto de un préstamo que solicito a un prestamista. Actualmente se encuentra instalada en el mercado de la Terminal en el costado Este de la Terminal de buses que llegan de otros departamentos.

Actualmente la señora B. tiene un puesto fijo con techo de zinc el mercado y recibe el apoyo de un nieto menor de edad el cual tiene la responsabilidad de mantener ya que no cuenta con sus padres de familia.

Consiente de la gran necesidad de la señora B., Ceprodel le ha brindado apoyo financiero desde hace dos años y medio con veinte créditos a su favor los cuales los ha sabido invertir en la remodelación de su local de trabajo y en el apoyo para la alimentación y vestido de su pequeño nieto.

texts.en:
Mariane S. currently rents her retail space. With a loan, Mariane wants to build her own shop to save money.

texts.es:
The economic activity that Maribel does is the sell of pants, blouses, t-shirts, etc. She's had her own business for 7 years. She got started with $1,500 that she and her husband were able to save.

She used to sell her goods through the streets of Nicaragua and later got established close to the bus terminal; this is where she currently keeps her stand. It's worth mentioning that before this business, she used to sell water around the streets of the city. She realized that this was not enough to cover her basic home needs, this is why she decided to sell clothes.

Maribel is married with 4 children, two of them have reached secondary school. This makes her very proud but at the same time its a challenge to keep them moving ahead during these difficult economic times. She really wishes to improve their living.

Ceprodel has given her the financial support she needs for over a year and a half and 10 credits. These credits have helped her business grow and at the same time is given her kids the food and education that her 4 children need. These kids are the most important thing in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica la señora Maribel es a la venta de pantalones, blusas, camisetas, etc. Actualmente posee 7 años de tener el negocio que se inició con un monto de C$1.500.00 alcanzado con el esfuerzo unido entre ella y su esposo.

Ella comenzó como vendedora ambulante viajando por los departamentos de Nicaragua para luego establecerse en el mercado la Terminal que es donde hoy en día se encuentra ubicada. Es digno de señalar que antes de tener este negocio, ella se dedicaba a la venta ambulante de agua pero se dio cuenta que no cubría la necesidad de su hogar por lo que prefirió iniciar la venta de ropa.

La señora Maribel es casada y con 4 hijos de los cuales dos de ellos ya han llegado a la secundaria. Esto llena de satisfacción a la señora Maribel pero además es un reto de seguir apoyando a sus hijos para que puedan salir de la dura situación económica que atraviesan y así poder mejorar su nivel de vida.

Ceprodel le ha brindado apoyo financiero desde hace año y medio habiendo obtenido un total de 10 créditos que le han ayudado en el crecimiento de su negocio y en la mejora económica para garantizarle el sustento y la educación a sus cuatro hijos que son lo mas importante de su vida.

loans.name: Matilde Benita

texts.es:
Her main economic activity is the selling of fruits such as apples, bananas, oranges, etc. It's been 10 years since she's had her business, it was a gift of C$800.oo given to her by her husband.

She began her business selling vegetables and is actually in a steady market located by the bus terminal. Mrs. C. is a single mom who works very hard to move ahead and support the 6 children that are actually attending primary and secondary school.

Ceprodel has given her financial support for over a year and a half and given her 15 credits. With these credits she has been able to buy more quantities of products that have allowed her increase her earnings; this way she has been able to support her 6 children who need their mom now more than ever.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Su principal actividad económica es la venta de frutas como manzanas, banano, naranjas, etc. Tiene 10 años de tener el negocio que se inicio con un aporte que le obsequió su esposo de C$800.00.

Inicia su negocio vendiendo solamente verduras y se ubica actualmente en el mercado de la Terminal en un puesto fijo que se encuentra al aire libre. La señora C. es madre soltera que viene luchando por salir adelante y apoyar a sus 6 hijos todos estudiando actualmente la primaria y secundaria.

Ceprodel le ha apoyado financieramente desde hace año y medio con un total de 15 créditos otorgados que le ha beneficiado por lo que ha comprado mayores cantidades de productos que le permiten obtener mayores ganancias para así seguir apoyando a sus 6 pequeños que hoy mas que nunca necesitan del apoyo de su madre.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for the stand

texts.en:
Nulu K. currently rents her retail space and wants a loan in order to build her own shop to reduce her expenses.

texts.es:
Mayela E. is a lady who dedicates her time to the sell of candy, cigarretes, etc. She has a son who she is a student, he attends primary school in one of the schools in the city. The business currently has been around for four years. It has given her a capital of $400 which her mom was able to help her with.

She began her business selling on the streets of Leon and right now she has a spot in the local street market of Leon right by the bus terminals. These bus terminals are very visited by others.

Thanks to the support she's been receiving from Ceprodel for over two years, she's been able to get 14 credits and invest in her business. She was able to improve her home living conditions.

Translated by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mayela E. es una dama que se dedica a la venta da dulces, cajetas, cigarrillos, etc. Tiene un hijo el cual está educando ya que cursa la primaria en uno de los colegios de la ciudad de León. El negocio actualmente tiene 4 años habiéndolo iniciando con un capital de C$400.00 producto de aporte que con mucho amor le obsequió su mamá.

Inició su negocio vendiendo con una canasta ambulante por las calles de León y actualmente se encuentra instalada en el mercado de la Terminal frente a una de las estaciones de buses que es muy visitada.

Gracias al apoyo que le ha brindado Ceprodel desde hace dos años con catorce créditos otorgados ha podido invertir más en su negocio y ha mejorado las condiciones de su hogar reconstruyendo su casa de habitación.

Miriam's business is the sales of food products (sauce tomatoes, vinegar and flavoring) and vegetables of all types. She's had this business for 16 years; she started the business with $500 in capital raised from her savings and those of her husband.

She started out selling spices and sauces in the streets of León. Currently her business is located in the market in the Terminal on the main street. Before she started this business Miriam was working as a cleaning lady in homes.

Miriam has received 19 loans from Ceprodel. As a result, she now has a fixed sales stall with a zinc roof in the market. We must also mention that Mrs. R. has 3 children. She fights to give them all the support they need in their deveopment as students so that in the future they will be educated people, with as great a love for their work as Miriam has for hers.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio de la señora Miriam se refiere a la venta de productos para la comida (como salsas de tomate, vinagre y condimentos), de igual manera a la venta de verduras. Tiene16 años de tener el negocio iniciando con un capital de C$500.00 alcanzados por medio de ahorros entre ella y su cónyuge.

Comenzó vendiendo especies y salsas de forma ambulante por las calles de León y actualmente se encuentra instalada en el mercado de la Terminal en la calle principal, antes de tener este negocio trabajaba como domestica a domicilio.

Ha realizado 19 créditos en Ceprodel por lo que hoy en día tiene un puesto fijo con techo de zinc en el mercado. No podemos obviar que la señora R. tiene tres hijos que lucha para brindarles todo el apoyo necesario en su desarrollo estudiantil para que en un futuro puedan llegar a ser personas muy preparadas y con gran amor a su trabajo como lo ha tenido la señora R..

loans.name: German Armando

texts.es:
German is 59 years old and is married with three children. All of his children are grown and two are married. German works as a carpenter, but due to the lack of work that he had, he saw the need to start a small clothing store out of his home. He and his wife manage the store together and he has had the store for two years now. His daughter is also living at home; she is a single mother. Because of this he alternates work between carpentery and the clothing store in order to earn enough income to support his family. He is asking for this loan to invest in the purchase of clothes for his store. Because the Christmas season is upon us, there is a much greater demand from his neighbors in the La Fuente neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Don German tiene 59 años de edad, casado y con tres hijos, todos mayores de edad y dos de ellos casados. Don German se dedica a la carpintería, pero debido a los pocos trabajos que obtiene, se vió en la necesidad de poner una pequeña tienda de ropa en su casa de habitación la que administra al lado de su esposa, tiene dos años de tener esta tienda.En su casa de habitación vive con una de sus hijas, que es madre soltera: es por eso que su trabajo lo alterna entre la carpintería y la tienda para poder generar los ingresos suficientes para la manutención de su familia. Requiere el crédito para invertirlo en ropa para su tienda, ya que en esta época navideña hay mucha más demanda por parte de sus vecinos del Barrio La Fuente.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for his additional clothing store business.

texts.es:
Nubia is a lady that for more than 10 years has dedicated her life to sell soda, juices, water, bakery threats, etc. She started with a capital of C$200.00, that was given to her by her husband.

She began selling as a street vendor in Leon but nowadays she is located on the market in the Terminal. She has a good client base, this is why every day before sunrise Nubia is up and ready to go.

She has a spot with a zinc ceiling, she managed to get this ceiling with a lot of hard work and the income her business generated. She fights hard, so she can provide good education and healthy lives for her two sons.

Ceprodel has helped her financially for about a year and a half. She has received eleven loans, which she has paid back completely. These loans helped her grow her business and improve her quality of life at home.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

Nubia es una dama que por mas de 10 años se ha dedicado a la venta de gaseosas, jugos, agua, reposterías, etc. Inició con un capital de C$200.00 producto de un aporte que le brindó su esposo para poner su propio negocio.

Inicia vendiendo ambulante por las calles de León y actualmente se encuentra instalada en el mercado de la Terminal en donde tiene buena clientela por lo que día a día antes de que salga el sol, la señora Nubia ya está lista para la venta de los refrescos.

Tiene un puesto fijo con techo de zinc, dicha mejora la realizo con mucho sacrificio de sus utilidades que le genera su actividad económica. Tiene dos hijos los cuales lucha para brindarles todo su apoyo en el desarrollo de sus estudios, salud y educación.

Ceprodel le ha apoyado financieramente desde hace año y medio con once créditos otorgados y pagados en tiempo y forma en donde el impacto que han tenido es en la mejora de sus ventas y su hogar de habitación.

Rosita’s primary business is the sale of clothing and footwear, which she started 15 years ago with an initial capital of $5000.00 which was contributed by her husband and her mother.

She started out helping her mother selling meat, but then decided to switch to selling clothing and footwear in which she has been successful enough because of the hard work that she does alongside her husband and because they used and reinvested their profits in the business.

Ceprodel has given Rosita unconditional support for a year and a half with a total of 7 loans which have been repaid. The impact of these loans has been many benefits in her business with an increase in inventory as well as her profits because she was able to provide better products of higher quality.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La principal actividad económica de doña Rosita es la venta de ropa y calzado, quien la inició hace 15 años con un monto inicial de C$5.000.00 producto del aporte del esposo y su mamá.

Ella inicia apoyando a su mamá vendiendo carne, pero luego decide cambiar al negocio de ropa y calzado el cual ha podido superarse satisfactoriamente por el arduo trabajo que ella realiza en conjunto con su esposo que han sabido utilizar o reinvertir sus utilidades en el negocio.

Ceprodel le ha brindado apoyo incondicional desde hace año y medio con un total de 7 créditos los cuales han sido cancelados oportunamente y el impacto que han tenido ha sido de mucho beneficio para su negocio ya que sus inventarios han aumentado al igual que sus utilidades obteniendo mejores productos y de mayor calidad.

texts.en:
This loan will allow Sarah N. to open a new selling space beside her existing store, where she sells charcoal.

texts.es:
Rosa C. is a very hard working mother that has been selling clothes for 20 years. She started this business with C$1,000.00, which she got from a loan.

She started selling clothes with a lot of effort and help from her three kids. She fights hard, so her kids can enjoy good health, decent education, good clothing and a solid moral foundation. We do have to mention that Rosa is a single mother and therefore her sales are the only income for the family.

Ceprodel has worked with her, on the last year and a half, they have helped her with 9 loans, these loans have served to strengthen her business and improve the quality of her house. Do to better earnings she had the opportunity of investing in her house and live happily with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa C. es una madre muy esforzada que se dedica a la venta de ropa que tiene desde hace 20 años el cual inició con un total de C$1.000.00 producto de un préstamo que realizó.

La venta de ropa la inicia con mucho esfuerzo con el apoyo de sus tres hijos que lucha al día a día para darles las condiciones necesarias de estudio, salud, ropa y respaldo moral. Cabe señalar que la señora Rosa es madre soltera y por tal motivo es el único sustento en su familia.

Ceprodel le ha brindado la mano en otorgarle créditos (9 créditos) desde hace año y medio que le han fortalecido su negocio y han mejorado la situación de su vivienda ya que obtiene mejores utilidades para reinvertir en su casita y vivir dignamente.

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
Flor de Maria is 35 years old, married and has one son who is in school. She lives in the Hialeah district. Flor de Maria and her husband are a young and hard-working couple. Wanting better living conditions, they began their business making mirrors, which they do together. They need this loan to buy raw materials to invest in the sale of mirrors, and with the profits earned that will build a room for their small son and give him a more comfortable life.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Flor de Maria tiene 35 años de edad, casado y con un niño en edad escolar, habitan en el barrio Hialeah. Flor de Maria y su esposo son una pareja joven y muy trabajadora. En busca de mejores condiciones de vida ingresaron al negocio de la elaboración de espejos, el cual lo hacen juntos. El crédito lo necesitan para comprar materia prima para invertirla en la comercialización de los espejos, y de las ganacias obtenidas poder construir un cuarto para su pequeño hijo y darle un vida más cómoda.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to make and sell mirrors

texts.es:
Mrs. M. during her married life, was a woman sorely dedicate to her house and had no type of business because the family survived with the income her husband provided. When her husband dies, she faces the necessity of establishing a business in order to provide for her and her son.

She starts selling clothes and cosmetics that she purchased with savings she kept over the years. Later on she manages to get a spot at the Leon Market in which she has kept a solid business.

She has been in business for twenty years and she has been very successful. With her new income she has managed to work with Ceprodel to increase sales, she has received 9 loans in the past two years.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. M. Durante su matrimonio era una mujer abnegada a su hogar y no tenia ningún tipo de negocio ya que sobrevivía de los ingresos de su esposo, al fallecer su esposo se ve con la necesidad de establecer un negocio por ser madre soltera y con un hijo en edad escolar.

Inicia la venta de ropa y cosméticos con los ahorros que mantenía del dinero que le facilitaba su esposo y posteriormente solicita un espacio en el mercado de León en donde logró establecerse hasta hoy en día.

Hasta la fecha de hoy, tiene veinte años de estar en el negocio teniendo buenos resultados ya que ha mejorado sus ingresos económicos por lo que ha solicitado el apoyo de Ceprodel quien la ha beneficiando con 9 créditos desde hace dos años.

Juanita worked most of her life in agriculture, she grew up in cotton-picking area and most of her family has worked in the same business. She is also a single mother, this is why she used her savings to start selling toys and little items on the street in different areas of the country.

Do to the effort and high risk she was incurring on these trips, she decide to stay working on a Market at Terminal de Leon, here she has her items for show in the second street of the market, where she pays daily for someone to store her inventory.

With Ceprodel she has been working for about a year and she has shown great use of the credit she got and excellent repayment history. They have granted her 7 loans and they all have been completely paid back and on time. These loans helped her increase sales; she uses this income to grow her business and to contribute to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Juanita, la mayor parte de su vida se ha dedicado al trabajo del campo, por habitar en una zona altamente algodonera y tradicionalmente su familia se ha dedicado a la agricultura. Además es madre soltera el cual inicia con sus ahorro otra forma de trabajo siendo esta la venta de juguetes o mercadería de temporada de forma ambulante ofrecidos en diferentes departamentos del país. Por el esfuerzo y el alto riesgo que tenia al realizar estos viajes decide quedarse trabajando en el mercado la Terminal de León, ubicando su mercadería en canastos al aire libre en la segunda calle del mismo mercado, donde paga diariamente bodega para su mercadería .

Con Ceprodel ha estado trabajando desde hace un año y ha demostrado dar buen uso de crédito y mantener su record crediticio excelente, se le han otorgado siete créditos todos cancelados en tiempo y forma por lo que hasta la fecha de hoy en día, la señora Juanita ha superado sus ventas obteniendo mayores ingresos económicos que los ha invertido en su familia y negocio.

Sra. H., with the support of her father, started working as a street vendor selling sweets all over Leon's La Terminal market. However, because she needed to improve her economic situation and because she was a single mother, she moved on to establish a business selling men's and women's clothing in one of the market spaces across from Leon's bus station.

Today, 20 years later, she's benefited enormously from the credit that Ceprodel has extended to her for the past three years, funds that she has used to maintain her humble household and to support her school-aged children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. H. con aporte de su papá inicia el negocio de de forma ambulante con la venta primeramente de galletas en todo el mercado La Terminal. Sin embargo, por la necesidad de mejorar su situación económica y además de ser madre soltera logra establecerse en un tramo ubicado frente a la estación de buses de León vendiendo ropa para damas y caballeros.

Hoy en día tienen 20 años de tener el negocio de ropa del cual desde hace tres años ha solicitado créditos en Ceprodel los que le han servido de mucho beneficio para el sustento de su humilde hogar y el apoyo a sus hijos que son infantes que ya están en el proceso de estudio en el colegio.

texts.en:
Justine K. is requesting a loan to allow her to open a new selling space beside her existing store where she sells fish and operates a restaurant.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

texts.es:
Before setting up his business, Sr. F. worked as a street vendor in Leon's La Terminal market. He sold various things but the little money that he earned wasn't enough to provide the things that he wanted for his family so he decided to apply for a loan that he used to start a soft-drinks business.

He's very grateful for the support that Ceprodel has provided him (37 loans) because his business has grown rapidly and he now has a wholesale business. He's even set up a small shop that supplies local street vendors with soft drinks for sale in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El Sr. F. antes de establecer su negocio de gaseosas se dedicaba al comercio de forma ambulante en todo el mercado la Terminal. Vendía productos comestibles pero por los pocos ingresos que le generaba este tipo de actividad no le permitía salir adelante con su responsabilidad familiar por el cual decide realizar un préstamo para poder iniciar su negocio de venta de gaseosas.

Actualmente se siente muy agradecido por el apoyo que le ha brindado Ceprodel por medio de los créditos (37 créditos) ya que su negocio ha incrementado rápidamente y ahora sus ventas son al por mayor, además ha logrado tener una mini bodega que abastece parte de la clientela que ofrece gaseosas ambulante por todo el mercado.

texts.en:
Ramula N. currently sells perishable food items like raw food and Irish potatoes. With a loan, Ramula wishes to add durable items to her store, like cooking utensils, which do not go bad if not sold right away.
