texts.es:
Before starting her business, Sra. M. worked as a hair stylist, working part of the time in a beauty salon and part of the time at home.

When she studied the options for setting up her own business, she decided with her husband to invest in the purchase of products for cutting hair. Today, the business continues to grow thanks to loans received from Ceprodel (19 loans) with which she has been able to buy new products for her business and above all to increase advertising to capture the attention of new customers.

Her hope is to continue with the credit plan offered by Ceprodel to improve her business even more and to pick up more customers for the services that her business offers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. M. antes de iniciar con su negocio se dedicaba a trabajar en un salón de belleza y a la vez realizaba trabajos a domicilio como estilista en horas de la tarde y los días domingo.

Al analizar la alternativa de poner un negocio propio, decide junto con su esposo invertir en la compra de los enseres para cortar cabello. Hoy en día, el negocio ha ido incrementando gracias a préstamos realizados en Ceprodel (19 créditos) con los cuales ha podido comprar nuevos enseres para su negocio y sobre todo aumentar la publicidad para captar la atención de nuevos clientes cada día.

De esta forma, son sus deseos seguir con el plan de créditos que le ofrece Ceprodel para mejorar aun más su negocio y poder ganar muchos clientes en los servicios que ofrece en el negocio.

For part of her life, Mrs. M. worked as a cleaner but, eight years ago, she decided to strike out on her own with the goal of helping her husband with household expenses and providing a better quality of life for their children.

She started as a street vendor in Leon's La Terminal market, selling costume jewelry, and looking, at the same time, for a permanent spot there to set up a business. A short time later, Mrs. M. was lucky enough to find a market stall and she's now meeting her targets for increased sales.

Mrs. M. owes her success to Ceprodel and the 41 loans that she has used to to gradually expand the products that she can sell in Leon's market.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Parte de su vida la Sra, M. se ha desempeñado como trabajadora domestica, desde hace ocho años decide trabajar por cuenta propia con el objetivo de apoyar a su esposo en los gastos de su hogar además de ofrecer un mejor nivel de vida a sus hijos.

Inicia vendiendo de forma ambulante en todo el mercado La Terminal con la venta de bisutería y a la vez solicita un espacio a la intendencia del mismo mercado para establecer su negocio sin ningún problema. Al poco temo la señora M. fue beneficiada con la entrega de un espacio por lo cual decidió establecer sus canastos y hasta la fecha ha logrado los objetivos propuestos como es incrementar sus ganancias.

Estos logros de la señora M. se deben exclusivamente al apoyo que solicitó en Ceprodel la cual le han otorgado 41 créditos que los ha podido aprovechar grandemente ampliando sus artículos de venta en el mercado de la ciudad de León.

Auxiliadora H. (known as Chilito) is a hard-working woman, a single mother with two children for whom she is both mother and father. Before she started her business, she eked out a living, travelling from place to place, selling products (spoons, bowls) made from wood. Because her income was small and the risks she ran to earn it great, she decided to look for a spot in Leon's Terminal market, ultimately finding an open-air stall there where she set up a business selling costume jewelry and other products.

Because Mrs. H. has long been aware of how necessary it is to invest in her business, she decided to join Ceprodel which has supported her with 6 loans, the money from which she has invested in her business.

Mrs. H. is very pleased and grateful for the support that Ceprodel has provided her, allowing her to improve her business so that she can now dream of adding inventory and even becoming an entrepeneur of some importance.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Auxiliadora Hernández (conocida como chilito) es una mujer muy trabajadora, madre soltera con dos hijos a su cargo donde ella es madre y padre. Para subsistir antes de establecer su negocio trabajaba de forma ambulante viajando a los diferentes departamentos para ofertar su productos procesados de madera (cuchara, jícara, etc) pero, por la poca ganancia que generaba este negocio y el riesgo de su vida en los viajes que realizaba además de dejar solo a sus hijos al cuido de una vecina, decide solicitar un puesto a la intendencia del mercado la Terminal, logrando tenerlo al aire libre en la segunda calle del mismo mercado donde coloca su venta de Bisutería o productos varios.

La señora Hernández al estar consiente de que es necesario invertir en su negocio, decide afiliarse a Ceprodel el cual la ha apoyado con 6 créditos que los ha invertido en su negocio.

La Sra. Hernández esta muy satisfecha y agradecida del apoyo que le ha brindado Ceprodel, por haber mejorado su negocio el cual hoy en día son sus mejores sueños incrementar sus artículos hasta convertirse en una empresaria de mucho prestigio.

Before starting this business, Mrs. U. worked as a bookkeeper for a local hardware store. When the store ran into financial problems, she was left out of work and her family with the earnings of her husband. She decided, then, to start her own business so that she could help with household expenses. When she was unemployed, Mrs. U., seeking ways to set up a business, decided on coffee sales and began looking for a shop in the Terminal market where she now has a cafe.

Ceprodel has provided Mrs. U. with 19 loans which she has invested in her business and today she not only sells coffee but also light snacks like bread and pastries that sell very well thanks to Mrs. U.'s kitchen skills.

It's been sixteen years now and business has been excellent because she's her own boss and her hope is to continue expanding the business so that she can improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Antes de iniciar con este negocio la Sra. U. se desempeñaba como contador de una ferretería de la ciudad, en cambio por la situación económica que atraviesa esta empresa, queda desempleada y sobrevive de los ingresos de su esposo, por lo que decide trabajar por si sola para ayudar a los gastos de su hogar como es su familia. Al estar desempleada la señora U. busca la manera de poner un negocio decidiéndose por la venta de café y para esto solicita un puesto en el mercado la Terminal logrando ubicar el cafetín donde se encuentra actualmente laborando.

Ceprodel le ha otorgado 19 créditos de los cuales los ha usado para invertir en su negocio de manera que hoy en día no solamente se encarga a la venta de café sino también de comidas livianas como pan y enmantecados que son muy vendidos por la habilidad que tiene la señora U. para cocinar.

Hasta la fecha tiene diecisiete años de estar establecida obteniendo buenos resultados ya que es dueña de su propio negocio y son sus deseos ir diversificando sus productos para obtener mejores niveles de vida.

Yolanda makes a living selling snacks, soft drinks and pastries in the market at Leon. She started the business 20 years ago with savings of C$1,000. It was very expensive to get started because she began as a street vendor, first selling water, then soft drinks as she slowly established a business at the Terminal market across from the local bus station.

It's important to point out that Ceprodel provided financial support to Yolanda for two years with a total of 14 loans that have improved her quality of life and increased her working capital so that she's been able to build a small canteen where she can better tend to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La actividad económica de doña Yolanda es la venta de refrescos, gaseosas y reposterías en el mercado de León. Tiene 20 años de tener el negocio iniciando con un monto de C$1.000.00 producto del ahorro que ella tenia. Como todo inicio le fue muy costoso ya que inició como vendedora ambulante de agua, gaseosas para posteriormente establecer mejor su negocio en el mercado la Terminal ubicada frente a la estación de buses.

Es necesario destacar que Ceprodel le ha brindado apoyo financiero por un periodo de dos años con un total de 14 créditos que han tenido impacto en mejorar su nivel de vida y en el aumento de su capital de trabajo logrando así la construcción de un cafetín en donde atiende a sus clientes con mejores condiciones.

texts.en:
The purpose of Janet M.’s loan is to purchase more products (increasing her stock), buy building materials, and pay for her children to go to boarding school. She has a market stall where she sells refrigerators, clothes, matooke (cooked, mashed bananas), and charcoal.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

The purpose of the loan to Harriet N. is to purchase more matooke so that her supplies are adequate.  Harriet also wishes to start a poultry farm and to buy a fridge with the loan.  She operates her business from a market stall.

Betty B. has a clinic, a poultry farm, a retail shop, and a beauty salon. With this loan, she wants to buy a microscope, build another poultry house, increase her stock, buy a generator, and build up her inventory so that she can supply other shops.

Grace N. has a beauty salon and, with a loan, wishes to purchase a generator, sitting dryer, and bigger mirror. She also wishes to buy cement to finish the floor in her house.

Mina N. is a tailor. She wishes to purchase an electric sewing machine and build a big table that can be used as the counter in her stall. She also wishes to purchase some chicks to rear for future income.

Vicencia K. has a beauty salon. With a loan, Vicencia wishes to buy hair oils for her shop.

Miriam L. has a retail store, a stone quarry, and rears cattle. She will use the loan to increase her stone inventory, buy more stones, purchase another farm, start a brick making business, purchase a calf and buy feed for her cow.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Mrs. Sabina dedicates herself to the sale of household commodities. She founded this business two years ago. She sells from door to door in various sectors of the city. One of her sisters helps her with the sales and recently her sales have increased. She wants to use her loan to invest in the purchase of merchandise now that her customers have made various requests for the holiday season and the new year. She does not have sufficient funds right now to satisfy her clients. Mrs. Sabina is 26 years old and has two children. Her house is made of reeds and her ultimate goal is to increase her sales so that one day she can situate her business right in her home. Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer

Descripción del Negocio

La Señora Sabina se dedica a la venta de artículos para el hogar , ella inicio este negocio hace dos años sus ventas lo realiza de forma ambulante en varios sectores de la ciudad, en sus ventas le ayuda una de sus hermanas y últimamente sus ventas han crecido.

Uso del Préstamo

Quiere usar su crédito para invertir en la compra de mercadería ya que sus clientes están realizando varios pedidos para la temporada y ella no tiene el suficiente capital para poder tener satisfechos a sus clientes.

Información Personal

Tiene 26 años y 2 hijos, su vivienda es de caña y su meta es crecer en sus ventas para un día poder instalar este negocio en su propia casa.

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To add more birds to her business

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary L. is requesting a loan to buy more items like vegetables, raw food, and tomatoes for her shop. With her increase in income, she hopes to be able to send her daughter to a boarding school.

loans.use: To increase the stock of her business

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence A. is a 40 year old married mother of 5 children (20, 16, 13, 11, 9) who is in the fish business. She wants the loan so she can invest in her current business and with the profits start a new business that sells more durable items like stationary.

loans.use: To invest in her current business and use the profits to start a new business

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice C. is a 27 year old married mother of 3 (ages 10, 6, and 3) who operates a charcoal business. She wants to expand the sell the charcoal business and use the loan with the proceeds of the charcoal sales to open a clothes selling business.

loans.name: Shakar Allah

texts.en: Shakar Allah lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives with his own family. He is an educated and very talented boy. He is a shopkeeper with a retail shop which opened one year ago. During this year he has attracted a lots of clients but he was unable to complete his stock so he has requested an individual loan to expand his business. He hopes to make good a income and help his family.

loans.use: To expand his business and complete his stock

loans.name: Mohammad Mosa

texts.en: Mohammad Mosa lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives with his own family. He is a doctor and also he has a drug store. He has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. He has good experience and he wants to expand his business so he wants to take an individual loan to import more medicine from Iran and Pakistan to attract more clients and make good income to help his family.

loans.use: To import more medicine from Iran and Pakistan

texts.en: Altaf Hussin lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with two daughters. He is uneducated but he is a carpet weaver with good experience. He has lots of students so he need to expand his business. He wants to take an individual loan to buy necessary materials and make his business popular in Kabul so that he can make a good income and help his family.

texts.ru:
Qudrat J. is 48 years old, has a high school education, is married and has 4 children. Qudrat has spent the past 5 years raising livestock and this constitutes his main source of income. He plans to use his loan to purchase 2 bulls to feed and sell. After selling them after a 40-45 day period he will purchase new bulls, feed them and then sell them, repeating the process during a 12 month period. After a full credit cycle he will earn 3 bulls as profit. Qudrat plans to pay back the loan over a 12 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Pardahol S. is 47 years old, has a high school education, is married and has 5 children. Pardahol plans to use the loan to purchase two bulls to feed and resell. She is confident that she will be able to handle this project as she has 10 years of experience in the area. After the sale of the bulls she plans to purchase younger, cheaper livestock to feed and resell after 40-45 days.

At the end of the credit cycle her profits will consist of 2 bulls that she plans to keep. Pardahol’s son helps her in her business. She plans to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.name: Said

texts.ru:
Said M. is 24 years old, has a college education and is an economist-programmer by profession. He is married with 2 children. Said currently works at “ITM Tajikistan.” He also owns a business that sells SIM cards and cards to refill mobile phone balances.

Said plans to use his loan to purchase SIM cards and cards to refill balances on mobile phones. His business helps mobile phone users to get the services that they need as there are a lot of people in Tajikistan that use cell phone services. Said plans to pay back the loan over a 12 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Муминов Саид, возраст – 24 года, образование высшее, по специальности – экономист - программист, женат, имеет 2-х детей. Саид в настоящее время работает в компании «ITM Tajikistan». Также он имеет диллерский центр по продаже сим-карт и карт для пополение баланса мобильного телефона. На полученный кредит он планирует приобрести сим-карты и карты для пополнения баланса мобильных телефонов. Диллерский центр помогает пользователям мобильной связи приобретать сим-карты для мобильных телефонов, а также карты пополения баланса, так как на сегодняшний день в Таджикистане оочень много человек пользующиеся услугами сотовой связи. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of SIM cards and refill cards

texts.en: Ragif A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 36 years old, married and has two children. He rents a small auto-repair shop in Beylagan. Ragif repairs radiators and other parts of cars. He needs a loan of $400 for buying materials which he will use at his shop.

Niyar A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 43 years old, married, and has three children. She sells women's clothes in the Beylagan city bazaar. She has engaged in this business for fifteen years. She wants to increase the variety of her goods and expand her business; because of this, she needs a loan in the amount of $700.

Jalal A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 25 years old and is single. Jalal owns and operates a small auto repair shop in Beylagan. He started his car repair business seven years ago. He needs a loan in the amount of $700 to buy spare parts and earn more income to improve his living.

Arif B. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 50 years old, married, and has three children. Arif is engaged in fruits and vegetables sales in the Beylagan city bazaar. He started his business ten years ago. Arif needs a loan in the amount of $1200 to expand his business.

loans.name: Shahin

texts.en: Shahin H. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 42 years old, married, and has two children. Shahin rented a small cafe in Beylagan. Shahin wants to buy new tables and chairs for his cafe. He needs a loan in the amount of $600.

loans.use: To buy tables and chairs for his cafe

texts.en: Zafer M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 23 years old and is single. Zafer has rented a small place near the market and has been busy with repair of mobile phones and the sales of phone accessories. He applied for the loan $500 to expand his business.

Atikah, 32 years old, and her husband E. are in gardening business - they grow flowers and plants for sale. The couple is usually able to earn US$12 a week. Atikah is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of US$125 to help expand her gardening business, so that she and her husband can increase their income and pay for their children's education. Atikah is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.name: Surayya

texts.en: Surayya M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 52 years old, married, and has seven children. She is selling women's clothes with her son in the Beylagan city bazaar. She wants to buy more kinds of goods, and because of this, she needs a loan in the amount of $600.

loans.use: To expand her clothing sales business

texts.en: Fakhraddin N. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 36 years old, married, and has three children. Fakhraddin has been driving a taxi for a few years. He needs a loan in the amount of $700 in order to purchase new tires for this taxi, as well as some minor repairs for his vehicle.

loans.name: Ai

texts.en: Ai J. is a 38-year-old woman who owns a small grocery store selling rice, snacks, vegetables, etc. She usually earns US$17 a week, while her husband Mad Sari does not have a permanent job. Ai is asking for a loan to buy various goods for her store. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for a grocery store

texts.en: Eldaniz G. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 45 years old, married, and has two children. Eldaniz owns a small butcher shop in Beylagan. He started his business seven years ago. He sells cow and sheep meat. He buys sheeps and cows at an animal market situated in Beylagan and sells them at his butcher shop. Eldaniz would like a loan in amount of $1100 to buy some sheep and to sell them at his butcher shop.

loans.name: Agha

texts.en: Agha A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 35 years old, married and has two children. Agha has got a lorry and he earns his family carrying luggage with his lorry. Now he needs a loan in amount $1200 for repairing his lorry.

loans.use: To expand business and repair lorry

texts.en: Karyati is a 38-year-old woman who has to work to pay for her day-to-day necessities and her children's tuition. She sells sheets and clothing on credit door-to-door in various places where she can find customers. Karyati usually earns US$33 a week with US$5.50 in profit. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan to help expand her business. Karyati is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Rahila A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 50 years old, married, and has two children. She is engaged in clothing sales in Beylagan city bazaar. She started her business seven years ago. Her daughter’s husband helps her in selling and his name is Khagani. (Khagani is pictured). Khagani goes to the Airport trading-center situated in the capital city, Baku, two times a month, and buys clothes for selling. Rahila needs a loan in amount of $500 to expand her business.

Rovshan R. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 43 years old, married, and has three children. He owns a small shop in Beylagan. He sells clothes, dishes etc. at his shop. He wants to buy more kinds of goods and because of this, needs a loan in the amount of $1200.

loans.name: Juriah

texts.en: Juriah is a 36-year-old woman who owns a small shop where she sells snacks, household goods, cigarettes, rice and many other things. She can usually earn US$44.50 a month, mostly due to the amount and variety of goods she has in stock. Her husband S. has no regular income, so she has to work hard to pay for her children's tuition. Juriah currently needs a loan of US$150 to increase the inventory stock in her shop. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory for a grocery store

texts.en: Parviz M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 25 years old, married, and has one son. He has been driving a taxi for a few years. He needs a loan in amount of $1000; he plans to repair his car that he uses as a taxi.

Eti is a 39-year-old woman who sells vegetables door-to-door in her village, thus earning US$11.50 a week. Previously, she sold food, but the business did not grow very well, so she decided to concentrate on vegetable sales. Her husband A. has no regular income. Eti is asking for a loan of US$150 to expand her vegetable retail business, and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Madina B. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 24 years old and has one son. She sells perfumes etc., in the Beylagan city bazaar. Her brother helps her at her job; (her brother is pictured). Madina needs a loan in theh amount of $500 to expand her business.

Deyanet A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 26 years old and is single. He owns and operates a small food-market near his home. He started his business five years ago. His brother helps him at his job. Deyanet would like to borrow $400 to buy more kinds of goods and expand his business.

Inah is a 42-year-old woman whose income source is production of bamboo matting. Before joining MBK, her husband S. was the only one who worked. But, since Inah joined MBK, she has been running her own matt-making business at her house, earning US$23 per month. She now needs a loan of US$150 to expand the business further, and is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

texts.es:
Mrs. Noemí B. is 32 years old and is married to Mr. Raúl Altamirano, who is 36 years old. They have lived together for 13 years and have a son in school.

When Noemí was very young she traveled with her mother to Argentina to work. While there she met Raúl and they got married and began to work very hard together for many years. The big hope of Noemí at this time was to return to her country and start her own business

Seven years ago Noemí returned to Paraguay. With the money that she and her husband saved they bought a livestock transport truck for her husband and she opened a car wash in the center of the city.

Thanks to the income they have generated from both businesses they were able to buy another truck. Today she is asking for a loan so that they can buy an air compressor for the car wash, now that every day she has more clients at the wash.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Noemí B., tiene 32 años de edad, está casada con el Sr. Raúl Altamirano (Argentino) de 36 años de edad, llevan 13 años juntos y tienen un hijo en edad escolar.

Noemí cuando era muy joven viajó con su mamá a la Argentina para trabajar, ahí es donde le conoció a Raúl, se casaron y empezaron a trabajar duro juntos durante varios años. El principal deseo de Noemí, en ese tiempo, era volver a su país y abrir su propio negocio.

Hace 7 años que volvió a Paraguay, y con el dinero que ella y su esposo ahorraron compraron un camión transportador de ganado para que trabaje su marido y ella montó un lavadero de vehículos en el centro de la ciudad.

Gracias a las ganancias que generaron ambos negocios pudieron comprar un camión más. Hoy solicita un préstamo para la compra de un compresor de aire para su lavadero, ya que cada vez tiene mayor cantidad de clientes en su lavadero.

texts.en: Napsah is a 56-year-old woman who makes a living producing bamboo matts. Before joining MBK, her husband S. was the only one who worked. But, since joining MBK, Napsah has been able to successfully run her own bamboo matting business at her house, usually earning US$20 per month. She is now requesting a loan to help further expand the business, and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Iyah is a 37-year-old woman who produces bamboo matting at her house. She usually earns US$22 per month. Her husband, S., has no regular income. Iyah is asking for a loan of US$125 to help her in business expansion. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Heriah is 38 years old. She earns her living producing bamboo matts at her house, usually making US$22.5 per month. Her husband, K., has no regular income. Heriah is asking for a loan of US$150 to help expand her matt-making business. She is a member of MBK, and, as a result, her business does increasingly well. She is willing to repay the current loan within 12 months.

loans.name: Amanecer Group

texts.es:
This group of women is from the Chaipe District in Paraguay. It has formed from the contact from another group of ladies from the same district. These women have had meetings related to the formation of this group and now they are a total of 15 women workers.

The activities that these ladies are involved with are: running pantries, laundry services, manicure & hair salon services, embroidery design, sale of foods, selling candy, selling jewelry, and running a social pharmacy.

Each member receives an average sum of 500,000 Gs. The purpose of these loans are to purchase goods and inventory required in their respective business, such as fabrics, thread, flour, sweets, sugar, clothing, jewelry, products for hair care, over the counter drugs/pharmaceutical items, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Este comité del Barrio Chaipe ha surgido por contacto de otras señoras de un comité del mismo Barrio, se han realizado las reuniones correspondientes para la conformación, y actualmente el comité esta formado por 15 mujeres trabajadoras.

Las actividades de estas señoras consisten en: despensas, lavandería, manicuras, peluquería, elaboración de bordados, venta de comidas, venta de dulces, venta de ropas, venta de joyas, farmacia social.

Cada integrante recibe en promedio la suma de 500.000 Gs. El destino de estos créditos son para comprar insumos y mercaderías necesarias en sus negocios, tales como: telas, hilos, harinas, panificados, dulces, azúcar, prendas de vestir, joyas, artículos para el cabello, medicamentos, etc.

loans.use: To purchase flour, canned goods, milk, soft drinks, fabric, clothing, jewelry, products for hair, over the counter drugs and health products, and thread.  (Compra de harina, productos enlatados, leche, bebidas, telas,  prendas de vestir, joyas, artículos para el cabello,  medicamentos, hilos, etc.)

loans.name: Adriana

texts.es:
Adriana is 36 years years old and her husband Santiago is 35 - they've been married for 13 years. The couple has two children, 11 and 9 years old, respectively. The children are both still in elementary school.

Adriana runs a well-stocked grocery store, while her husband works as a policeman.

She says she started her business with great sacrifice because they had little money. Besides, when she started the business, her second child was born, and her husband's income did not cover the household expenses.

Now she can state with satisfaction that her business is going very well. She has good sales and has formed a good clientele.

Their short term goal is to complete a building (which is already in construction), for the purpose of expanding her grocery store.

Now, she is seeking credit for the purchase of goods such as rice, oil, sugar, flour, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Adriana tiene 36 años y está casada hace 13 años con Santiago que tiene 35 años de edad. El matrimonio tiene dos hijos de 11 y 9 años respectivamente. Ambos aún van a la escuela primaria.

Adriana posee una despensa bien surtida, mientras que su esposo es policía.

Ella comenta que inició su negocio con mucho sacrificio debido a que contaba con poco dinero para iniciar tal actividad. Además en ese tiempo nació su segundo hijo y los ingresos de su marido no cubrían los gastos del hogar.

Ahora cuenta con satisfacción que su negocio marcha muy bien, tiene buena venta y ya ha formado buena clientela.

Su proyecto a corto plazo es el de terminar una construcción que ya ha iniciado y que será destinado a la ampliación de su despensa.

En esta oportunidad solicita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías como arroz, aceite, azúcar, harina, etc.

loans.use: To purchase oil, sugar, rice, soft drinks, juices, sweets, etc. (Compra de aceite, azúcar, arroz, gaseosas, jugos, panificados,etc.)

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is 49 years old. She is married to Antonio who is her same age. The couple has two children who are 20 and 16 years old. The oldest son is following the course of admission to enter a university while still studying in high school.

Carmen owns a grocery store where she began working 40 years ago and she explains that it was owned by her father until it died 10 years ago, so he left it for her to run.

Her husband is a carpenter by profession, and with the income he generates, helps with the household expenses.

The grocery store Carmen runs is well stocked and has a good clientele. Their project in the short term is to invest in building a bigger room so they can expand their grocery store.

Now she is requesting a loan to buy flour, sugar, sweets, beverages like soda, juice, wine, cider, etc., since the Christmas and New Year holidays will bring in customers who will want to purchase these products.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Carmen tiene 49 años. Está casada con Antonio que tiene la misma edad que ella. La pareja tiene dos hijos de 20 y 16 años respectivamente. El mayor de los hijos está siguiendo el cursillo de admisión para ingresar a una carrera universitaria mientras que la menor aún continúa estudiando en la secundaria.

Carmen es propietaria de una despensa que funciona hace 40 años y según comenta ella, la misma era propiedad de su padre hasta que este falleció hace 10 años, quedándose Carmen al frente de la misma.

Su esposo es carpintero de profesión, y ayuda, con los ingresos que genera su trabajo, con los gastos del hogar.

La despensa de Carmen se encuentra muy bien surtida y cuenta con buena clientela. Su proyecto a corto plazo es invertir en la construcción de un salón más grande con el fin de surtir más su negocio.

Ahora necesita de un préstamo para la compra de harina, azúcar, panificados, bebidas como gaseosas, jugos, vinos, sidra, etc. ya que en las fiestas de navidad y año nuevo aumentan las ventas de estos productos.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, sweets, soft drinks, juices, wine, cider, etc. (compra de harina, azúcar, panificados, bebidas como gaseosas, jugos, vinos, sidra, etc.)

loans.name: Daisy

texts.es:
Daisy is a young woman who is 21 years old. She's been almost married for one year to the person she's been living with for 4 years. They have two small children whom they adore.

Daisy is a seamstress and previously worked for a person who paid for all the work she completed. She currently has three sewing machines, that are set up in her living room.

She now wants to build a small workshop where she'll be able to work with greater ease because the space that she now has available is very limited.

Currently she is in need of a loan which will be invested in the purchase of a sewing machine which will handle the work which is in high demand.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Deisy es una joven mujer de 21 años que se casó hace apenas 1 año con la persona con quien convivió primeramente por un lapso de 4 años. Tienen dos hijos pequeños que son la adoración de la pareja.

Deisy es costurera y comenta que anteriormente trabajaba para una persona que le pagaba por los trabajos terminados. Hoy día ya cuenta con tres máquinas de coser propias que están instaladas en la sala de su casa.

Desea construir un pequeño taller en donde trabajará con mayor comodidad debido a que el espacio que dispone ahora es muy reducido.

Actualmente necesita de un préstamo que será invertido en la compra de una máquina más debido a que tiene mucha demanda.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine.  (compra de una maquina de coser)

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia is 56 years old, living with her partner Pablo who is 52 years old. They have 4 children (all adults now).

Eugenia runs a grocery store, while Paul works as a driver for a business that sells bricks.

Eugenia began her business 10 years ago when she decided to stop making & selling chipas (typical Paraguayan meal made out of starch), because it was affecting her health.

Today she has a good assortment of products and a good clientele.

She says that thanks to the revenue generated by their small business, in addition to the profits that Pablo makes with his work, they have managed to raise their 4 children, who have become professionals.

She is now requesting a loan to supplement her inventory so she can get ready for the holiday season.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Eugenia tiene 56 años, vive en pareja con Pablo que tiene 52 años de edad. Tienen 4 hijos, todos ya mayores de edad.

Eugenia posee una despensa mientras que Pablo trabaja como chofer para un negocio de venta de ladrillos.

Eugenia comenzó con su negocio hace 10 años cuando decidió dejar la elaboración y venta de chipas (comida típica paraguaya hecha a base de almidón) debido a que dicha actividad afectaba su salud.

Hoy día cuenta con un negocio bien surtido y con una clientela bien formada.

Afirma que gracias a los ingresos que genera su pequeño negocio, además de las ganancias que Pablo obtiene en su trabajo, ha logrado criar a sus 4 hijos quienes hoy se han convertido en profesionales.

Solicita el crédito para surtir mejor su negocio debido a que se acercan las fiestas de fin de año.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, flour, rice, noodles, soft drinks, juices, fruits, vegetables, canned goods, and sweet breads, etc. (compra de azúcar, harina, arroz, fideo, gaseosas, jugos, frutas, vegetales, productos enlatados, pan dulces, etc.)

loans.name: Eulalio

texts.es:
Eulalio is 34 years old. He lives with his partner Lorenza (32 years old). They have two sons, 10 and 7 years, respectively, and both children are still in elementary school.

Due to the fact that he came from a very poor family, he was unable to complete his studies and only completed his studies through 6th grade.

Eulalio is automotive electrician, and says that he began working as an assistant from the time he was 12 years old, until he managed to become independent at the age of 18 years, when he constructed his own shop in a rented space.

He states that he's doing very well in his business, and has had enough clientele and work throughout the year.

He is now in need of a loan to make improvements in his current space (he wants to build a small shed) and purchase more tools that are necessary in his daily tasks.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Eulalio tiene 34 años, vive en pareja con Lorenza de 32 años y tienen dos hijos de 10 y 7 años respectivamente. Ambos niños están estudiando aún en la primaria.

Debido a que provenía de una familia muy humilde, no pudo terminar sus estudios, llegando a completar solamente hasta el 6to. Grado de la educación primaria.

Eulalio es electricista de automóviles; comenta que comenzó a trabajar como ayudante desde los 12 años hasta que logró independizarse a la edad de 18 años montando su propio taller en un local alquilado.

Afirma que le va muy bien en su negocio, cuenta con bastante clientela y tiene trabajo durante todo el año.

Necesita un préstamo para realizar mejoras en su local (construcción de un pequeño tinglado) y compra de más herramientas que les son indispensables en su tarea diaria.

loans.use: To build a shed and purchase tools. (construcción de un tinglado y compra de herramientas)

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario is 38 years old and lives with his partner Maria Luisa who is 40 years old. The couple has 2 older kids who still live with them.

Mario began working at the age of 14 with a Korean person who taught him everything related to the repair of air conditioners.

When he turned 20 he was able to be go on his own and got his own shop, he is currently leasing the place. Today he has all the tools required to complete his job and at teh same time he is able to employ his brothers.

He repairs all kinds of electronics but his focus is on air conditioners, refrigerators and washing machines.

He needs a loan to purchase broken electronics so that he can fix them and re-sell them to a lower cost. This way he can increase his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mario tiene 38 años y vive en pareja con María Luisa que tiene 40 años de edad. La pareja tiene 2 hijos ya mayores de edad pero que aún viven con ellos.

Mario comenzó a trabajar a los 14 años en un taller propiedad de un coreano en donde aprendió todo lo relacionado a la profesión de técnico en refrigeración.

Cuando cumplió 20 años logró independizarse y montó su taller propio que funciona en un local alquilado. Hoy día cuenta con todas las herramientas necesarias para realizar su trabajo y además le da empleo a uno de sus hermanos.

Repara todo tipo de electrodomésticos pero su punto fuerte lo constituyen los acondicionadores de aire, heladeras y lavarropas.

Necesita de un préstamo para la compra de electrodomésticos en desuso que repara y luego vuelve a vender a un bajo costo obteniendo de esa manera muy buenos ingresos.

loans.use: Purchase of used items such as air conditioners, washing machines, refrigerators, etc.

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Marta has been living with Rolando, her partner, for 8 years. She is 23 years old and he is 29. Marta is a seamstress and Rolando works in a brick yard.

She began work as a seamstress since she was 15 years old and its been a year since she got her own sewing machine. This machine has been installed in the workshop of the person she works for.

Her greatest wish is to have her own shop in her house since she's currently pregnant with her first child and this way she could stay home, take care of the baby, and continue her job as a seamstress.

For this reason she would like to complete her own sewing shop.

Translated by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Marta vive en pareja hace 8 años con Rolando, ella tiene 23 años y él 29. Marta es costurera y su pareja trabaja en una olería (lugar donde se fabrican ladrillos).

Ella comenzó a trabajar desde los 15 años en la costura y hace un año que cuenta con una máquina propia pero que está instalada en un taller de costura propiedad de la persona a quien le entrega los trabajos terminados.

Su mayor deseo es terminar su tallercito en el fondo de su casa debido a que está embarazada de su primer hijo y de esa forma podría quedar al cuidado del mismo, a la par de continuar realizando sus labores de costura.

En esta oportunidad necesita de un préstamo par terminar el taller ya mencionado.

loans.use: Completion of her sewing shop in her own home.

loans.name: Ursina

texts.es:
Ursina is 55 years old. She is single and has no children. She is an architect and although she works in her profession, her biggest source of income comes from the three passenger buses she owns and runs as a business.

She tells us that she started in the transportation business 13 years ago ago when her mother died, which forced her to look for something with which to pass the time since she was going through a rough period.

This is how she got the idea of buying a bus to offer transportation services throughout the city of Itá. First she bought a bus with the savings she had, and then she hired a chauffeur, while she worked as a security guard for the passengers on the bus. Later, due to the success of her business, she had the opportunity to acquire two other buses, and to date, she has three buses that continue to make these trips.

The loan she is requesting is to purchase new roofing for one of her buses.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Ursina tiene 55 años, es soltera y no tiene hijos. Es arquitecta y aunque aún ejerce su profesión, su mayor fuente de ingresos económicos lo constituyen los tres autobuses de pasajeros que son de su propiedad.

Comenta que se inició en el negocio del transporte hace 13 años atrás, cuando falleció su madre, motivo que la obligó a buscar algo con qué distraerse para hacer pasar el mal momento que dicha situación le ocasionó.

Tal es así que surgió la idea de comprar un autobús que hacía su itinerario por diferentes pueblos de la ciudad de Itá. En un principio adquirió un bus con los ahorros que tenía guardados y contrató a un chofer, mientras ella oficiaba de guarda (persona que cobra el pasaje). Más adelante, debido al éxito de su negocio, tuvo la oportunidad de adquirir otros dos transportes más y a la fecha cuenta con tres unidades que continúan haciendo dichos viajes.

En esta oportunidad necesita de un préstamo para la compra de cubiertas nuevas de uno de sus buses.

loans.use: To purchase a new roof for one of her buses. (compra de cubiertas nuevas)

texts.es:
Rosalía Benítez is from Carapeguá city, is 47 years old, and has been married to Mario Santacruz for 20 years. They have two daughters in the university. They live in their own home which they have built with much sacrifice.

When she was younger she traveled to Argentina to work as a domestic employee in order to help her family, and there she met her husband. They returned to Paraguay and with some savings they began to work together. First they sold artesan goods on the street, but as they had friends that lived in Argentina they decided to try selling Argentinian watches and the result was rather positive; so their friends that live in Argentina send them large quantities of merchandise so they can sell them here in Paraguay.

Today they are asking for a loan in order to purchase a large quantity of watches, as selling them generates very good earnings and the wholesale purchase of these products generates greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Rosalía Benítez es de la ciudad de Carapeguá tiene 47 años de edad esta casada con el Señor Mario Santacruz hace 20 años. Tienen dos hijas las dos en etapa universitaria, viven en casa propia que lo han construido con mucho sacrificio.

De joven viajó a la Argentina para trabajar como empleada doméstica para así poder ayudar a su familia, allí conoció a quien actualmente es su esposo. Volvieron a Paraguay y con unos ahorros que juntaron empezaron a trabajar juntos. Primeramente con la venta ambulante de artesanías, pero como tenían familiares que vivían en la Argentina decidieron probar vender relojes fabricados en Argentina y el resultando fue bastante positivo; es así que sus familiares que viven en Argentina les envían las mercaderías en grandes cantidades para que ellos los comercialicen aquí.

Hoy día ellos solicitan el crédito para poder adquirir mayor cantidad de relojes, pues la venta genera muy buenas ganancias y la compra al por mayor de estos productos les genera mayor ganancia.

texts.en:
Maria S. is a 40 year old married mother of 6, ages 25 to 16, who raises poultry and cows on her farm. She wants a loan to construct more poultry houses. With her profits she hopes to construct a new home on her plot.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.name: Amelia Sánchez

texts.en: Amelia is a skilled and energetic businesswoman who owns a grocery store that she started five years ago. She is 42 years old, married and has three children, all of whom are in school. The store is well known in her community, and people love to go there because the quality is high and she is a very kind person. Amelia would like to expand her business and make it even more-frequently visited and profitable. She has requested a loan to buy more goods to sell in her store. She is especially eager to acquire her new inventory now because she needs the income to pay her children’s tuition and proviD. food and other items for her family.

loans.use: To replenish supplies at a grocery store.

loans.name: Estervina Severino

texts.en:
Estervina is a many-sided businesswoman. She runs a cafeteria and sells vegetables in the public market. She operates the cafeteria just on weekends; during the week, you can see her next to her stall selling her fresh vegetables. Estervina is fifty years old and she has nine children, eight of them boys.

With her loan, Estervina plans on purchasing raw materials for her cafeteria and more vegetables to keep selling in the public market. She explains that she has gained a lot of experience from these long and arduous years of hard work. She says she will keep on working a lot to improve her and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase materials for a cafeteria and vegetables for a small business.

loans.name: Estervina Severino

texts.en: Estervina is a very active businesswoman who runs a cafeteria and also sells vegetables in the public market.  She operates the cafeteria on weekends only, when demand is greatest. During the week, you can see her in a stall in the public market selling her fresh vegetables. Estervina is 50 years old and has nine children, eight of whom are boys. She plans to use her loan to buy raw materials for her cafeteria, and more vegetables to sell in the public market.  She is very confident that she use her loan well because of the experience she has acquired during many busy and arduous years of work.  She is also determined to keep working hard to improve her her own life as well as the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy materials for a cafeteria and vegetables for a small business.

loans.name: Ramona Leyba

texts.en: Ramona is 31 years old and the single mother of three children. For the last year and a half, she has run a business selling ice cream and fried and grilled chicken. Her business has grown rapidly, with many customers coming to her stall daily for her delicious meals. Ramona wants to rent a small shop from which to run her business, and has applied for a loan to buy the materials she needs to expand her operations. These include plucked chickens, spices, vegetable oil and other goods. She will also use part of the money to rent her store.  Ramona believes that her business will be successful and allow her to better support her family.

loans.use: Buy materials and plucked chickens for a fried-foods store.

texts.en:
Sarah N. is a 48 year old married mother of 4 children, 30, 28, 27, 26, who raises layers (chickens) and pigs. She wants the loan to purchase small pigs to rear.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

Christine M. is a 50 year old married mother of 10 children. She currently raises pigs and wants the loan to open a retail shop. With the profits she hopes to begin another business in cow rearing.

loans.name: Petronila Vizcaino

texts.en:
Petronila is fifty years old and has seven grown children. Some of them are married and living on their own while the others are in college. Petronila is a seamstress, and for the last 23 years has run a clothing-making business out of her house. She is very experienced and skilled, and a lot of people stop by to purchase her products.
Petronila wants to enlarge her business by hiring one or two employees next year. She has come to us for a loan to buy cloth, thread and other material she needs to meet her clients’ needs.

loans.use: Purchase materials to make new clothing to sell

loans.name: Merita

texts.en: Merita is in her late thirties and the mother of four children. The eldest goes to university, and the younger ones are in secondary school. Merita makes a living selling fresh vegetables and legumes.  She has been this business for six years, is well known for her produce and has lots of customers. Merita's long-range goal is to rent a stall where she can sell her goods, because this will allow her to expand her business and make her customers more comfortable. Merita has applied for a loan to buy a large quantity of vegetables to sell, so that she will not need to leave her community to acquire new stock for the next two weeks. Her goal is to increase her income so that her family can live more comfortably and she can pay her son's university tuition.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to restock a small business

loans.name: Juana

texts.en: Juana is 34 years old, married and the mother of four children, three girls and one boy.  For the last five years, she has run a small restaurant in the local public market, where she serves traditional Dominican meals and juices.  Her business is doing well, with many customers stopping by daily for her specialties, such manioc with boiled or fried eggs for breakfast, or rice with beans and chicken or spaghetti with salami for lunch. On Dec. 31, she plans to prepare a ‘sancocho’ – a traditional meal maD. with chicken, pork chops, sausage, plantain bananas and other ingredients -- to serve at 11 p.m. She has done this for the last five years, and it has been hugely popular in her town. Juana has applied for a loan to buy the items she needs to run her restaurant, such as food and disposable plastic plates, and hopes that continued success will help her care for her children.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and other items for a small restaurant.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina is in her early thirties, and for the last eight years has operated a grocery store.  Her business is popular because of the many items she has to sell, and because she is such a kind and thoughtful person. Catalina is committed to protect and expand this tradition of excellence in customer service so that her business can keep growing. She plans to do that with a new loan, which will allow her to purchase new items -- such as beer, rice and fresh pork -- to sell to her customers. Catalina's long-term goal is to open a new store in a location she owns, because this will allow her to increase her income and take better care of her six children.

loans.use: To restock her store with items to sell

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Hường is 33 years old. She is married and has 4 children who are still attending school. They live in Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An (north central province of Vietnam). Ms Hường is a TYM member since 200. Her first loan was 50 USD which was invested in raising pigs & poultry. After 5 years, she has acquired lots of experience so the production has raised as well. She decided to borrow more money to invest in her business. Her investment was well managed, her revenue is now 125 USD a month. She's requesting a new loan of 575 USD to buy chickens, pigs and feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hường, 33 tuổi, Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2001. Gia đình chị gồm hai vợ chồng và 4 đứa con đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Với mức vay đầu tiên là 50USD chị đã đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Qua 5 năm số vốn và kinh nghiệm sản xuất tích lũy tăng dần, chị chủ động nâng mức vốn mở rộng dự án chăn nuôi của gia đình. Sử dụng những đồng vốn rất có hiệu quả với mức thu nhập 125USD/tháng, dự định chị sẽ xin vay 575USD để mua thêm lợn, gà cùng thức ăn gia súc.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Vân, 40 years old, is a participating member since 2001. Her first loan of 65 USD was invested in opening a home based micro brewery producing rice wine and also making fresh rice vermicelli. Her husband is in charge of the production, he also helps serve the customers. After 5 years, the business is quite stable, it brings in about 100 USD a month. She's requesting a loan of 625 USD to buy rice to make wine and vermicelli and to expand her business thus raising her family income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Vân, 40 tuổi, tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 2001. Với mức vốn ban đầu chỉ có 65USD, chị đã đầu tư vào mở cửa hàng ăn uống vụ bà con trong vùng. Anh Dũng, chồng chị Vân cũng tích cực giúp đỡ vợ trong việc sản xuất cũng như phục vụ tại cửa hàng. Sau 5 năm kinh doanh, đến nay chị đã có một cơ sở sản xuất tương đối đầy đủ với mức thu nhập 100USD/tháng. Dự định chị Vân sẽ xin vay 625USD ở vòng vốn tiếp theo mua thêm gạo làm bún và nấu rượu với mục đích tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.

loans.use: Buy rice to make vermicelli and brew rice wine

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Thu

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Thu Hằng, 35 years old, lives in Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An (north central province of Vietnam ) with her husband and 2 children. After seeing her friends having success in their business with the loan from TYM fund, she had decided to join TYM and borrowed 65 USD. She invested in pig breeding. After 2 years of this she had switched to retails. With all her savings and a loan, she has opened a grocery store selling candies, cookies, beer, liquor ...etc. She is planning on expanding her store, adding more merchandise so she requests a loan of 450 USD. Her actual monthly income is 125 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by KH. Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Thu Hằng, 35 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và hai con tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An. Sau khi Quỹ Tình thương về hoạt động tại Nghi Lộc được một thời gian, thấy chị em vay vốn làm ăn có hiệu quả, chị Hằng đã tham gia vào Quỹ và xin vay mức 65USD. Sau hai năm đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, với kết quả thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và đồng vốn vay từ năm thứ 3 chị đã chuyển sang đầu tư vào mở cửa hàng buôn bán các mặt hàng bánh kẹo bia rượu v.v... Dự định trong thời gian tới chị sẽ xin vay 450USD để mở rộng các mặt hàng kinh doanh. Thu nhập hiện nay của chị Hằng là 125USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy goods for her grocery store.

loans.name: Cridia

texts.en: Cridia is a young businesswoman and mother of three daughters, aged 8, 7 and 2.  Her husband makes a living driving a taxi. For the last two years, Cridia has helped her husband support their family by selling boiled beans and plucked chickens. She uses her income to buy items her family needs and to pay for the education of her children. Cridia's long-term goal is to open a large store that is visited by not just by the people of her town, but by people who live in surrounding communities as well. She is working hard to achieve that goal, and has come to us for a loan to buy beans and chickens that she can sell to her customers.

loans.use: Purchase beans and chickens needed to run a small business.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia is in her late thirties and has three children, all of whom attend school.  She makes a living in two ways: selling new and used clothing to the women of her community, and preparing lunches that she sells from her house.  Eugenia sells clothing by walking up and down the streets of her community to see if anyone would like to make a purchase. She leaves early in the morning and returns at about 11 o’clock to begin preparing lunches with the help of a young assistant. Eugenia has applied for a loan to buy clothing in bulk and ingredients she uses to prepare and sell her delicious food.

loans.use: To buy clothing in bulk to sell in her community, and to buy ingredients to prepare food.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolanda is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. For more than three years, she has operated a store where she sells men’s and women’s clothing. Every two years, she travels to Santo Domingo, her nation's capital, to get new garments at very cheap prices. Her store is well known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Yolanda hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for herself and her four children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: Buy clothing in bulk to sell to her customers

loans.name: María

texts.en: María is the mother of six children and for the last eight years has run a small pastry shop in Yamasá. She is a skilled businesswoman with lots of experience and is deeply familiar with the rules of the marketplace. After years running her business at a rented location, Maria's long-term goal is to open a new shop at a location she owns. In the meantime, she plans to continue to work diligently and patiently until she can achieve that dream. She has applied for a loan to buy the ingredients she needs to prepare cakes, cookies, pastries and pies for her customers.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for a pastry shop

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: Mrs. Tes Y., 58, is a mother of one child and lives with her husband in Bathambong province, Cambodia. She runs a stand at home selling boiled duck eggs, grilled chicken, candy, biscuits and other provisions to the people in her area, making on average about $5/day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and generally makes about $3 each day. Mrs. Tes Y. hopes to use this loan to expand her business by purchasing more products to meet her clients’ needs and use the remainder of the money to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more products to meet her clients’ needs and use the remainder of the money to reinvest in her business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been paid back early.

Thanks to your support of entrepreneurs like Tes Yan, small businesses around the world are able to access low-interest loans to help their businesses. We hope that you will continue this support through Kiva and CREDIT.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

texts.en: Mrs. Moa T., 33, is a widow and lives with her two little kids in Bathambong province, Cambodia. In order to service in her family’s expenses, she grows variety of vegetable and sells them at an open air market, making around $3/day. Mrs. Moa T. hopes to use this loan to purchase mushroom seeds.  Mushroom prices are steadily rising and she wants to meet her customers' growing demands.

payments.comment:
Congratulations to Moa Thoeun for paying back your Kiva loan early! Thank you for supporting the success of poor Cambodian entrepreneurs. We hope you will continue to invest with CREDIT in the future.

Best regards,
The team at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh, Cambodia

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy soldering wires and pay for electricity to improve his business.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim S., 48, is a widow and lives with her three unemployed children in Bathambong province, Cambodia. To cover her family's expenses, she works as a tailor and typically makes about $5/day.  Her customer base is mostly the people in her community. Sim S. has recently requested for a loan to purchase more cloth, sewing thread and tools for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth, sewing thread and tools for her tailoring business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been paid back ahead of time.

Thanks to your support of entrepreneurs like Sim Savith, small businesses around the world have access to low-interest loans to help their business.

We hope you will continue loaning through Kiva and CREDIT MFI.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow,
Cambodia

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shoe stock for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase equipment for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add to her stock of used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add to her stock of used clothing

texts.en: Sayaad Haroon lives in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and he lives with his own family. He is the only to support for his family and he has plots of land for cultivate. He is unable to further this business so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his lease purchase to start working on his land and make a good income to help his family and make bright future for himself.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his milk selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase equipment for his milk selling business.

texts.en: Mohammad Harf lives in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with one son. He has a shoemaking shop in Kabul and he has good experience. He was in Pakistan for about 8 years and when he came back two years ago he started this business. Now he would like to expand his business so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his stock to sell new kinds of shoes in the bazaar to enlarge his business and make a good monthly income to help his family.

Joy B. is a 38 year old mother of 4 who rears local poultry breeds. She wants the loan to construct a poultry house and, eventually, to expand her business to be a wholesale supplier of chickens.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

Norah N. is a 49 year old divorced mother of 6 who raises pigs. She wants the loan to build more pig sties and breed more piglets. She eventually wants to expand her business and become a specialist pork supplier.

loans.name: Jesca's Group

texts.en:
Jesca N. is a 32 year old married mother of 4, ages 11, 9, 6, and 3, who sells used clothing. She wants the loan to increase her stock and plans to invest the additional profits to start a piggery business.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothing

loans.name: Tolibjon

texts.en: Tolibjon N. lives in B.Gafurov rayon; he is married and has 2 children. Tolibjon N. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 and recommends himself as a serious and highly motivated client. Loan sums are permanently increased to those who show business stability and an income increase. He is a mechanical engineer and tractor driver. Mr.N. has a wide business including livestock raising and selling and milk production. He wants to purchase a horn pedigree bull and milk cow for further meat and dairy goods production (to supply to bazaars). It is planned to include to the assortment the following milk products: pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream, curds, etc. Now Mr.N. requires a loan of 1,800 TJS (US$525) for a horn pedigree bull and pedigree milk cow purchase, which will allow him to increase significantly the family income and further business development.

loans.use: horn pedigree bull and pedigree milk cow purchase

texts.en:
Jowfma N. is a 47 year old mother of 5 children (30, 25, 18, 11, 5) who currently operates a restaurant. She wants this loan to open a retail shop. With the profits she hopes to purchase a commercial motorcycle for rent (a “boda-boda”).

Grace N. is a 50 year old married mother of 7 (ages 20, 28, 26, 24, 18, 17, 13) who currently grows and sells cassava. She wants the loan to begin rearing local poultry breeds and intends to use the profit to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Khaidarhoja

texts.en: Khaidarhoja N. lives in Gonjy; he is married and has 1 child. Khaidarhoja N. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 and recommends himself as a serious and strongly motivated client. Loan sums are permanently increased to those who show business stability and an income increase. He  has a wide business including livestock raising and selling as well as milk production. He wants to purchase a horn pedigree bull and milk cow for further meat and dairy goods production (to supply to bazaars). It is planned to add to the assortment the following milk products: pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream, curds, etc. Now Mr. N. requests a loan of 1,800 TJS (US$525) for a horn pedigree bull and a pedigree milk cow, which will allow him to increase significantly the family income and to  further widen the business.

loans.use: horn pedigree bull and pedigree milk cow purchase

texts.en:
Getu L. is a 45 year old married mother of 9 children (ages 29, 28, 25, 24, 18, 16, 15, 13, 10) who trades in cereal grains and pigs. She wants the loan to expand her piggery business and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Otunoi

texts.en:
S. Otunoi has just celebrated her 29th birthday. Otunoi is the loving mother of 2 children. Both of them are of school age. Otunoi’s husband workw only in summer which is why Otunoi is the main bread-winner in her family.

Otunoi has been selling the foodstuff for 7.5 years. She started as a seller and gradually she became able to have her own trading place. During the last 3 years, Otunoi was provided with several loans by IMLF IMON for expanding her business. Every time she borrowed, Otunoi was very exact and accurate in payments.

At the present time, Otunoi is selling candies and sweets. Before the New Year she is planning to purchase candies, sweets and festive packages. Otunoi wants to assemble and sell sweet gifts for kids. For this purpose she is requesting 800.00 US dollars. Otunoi wishes everybody Merry Christmas and Happy New Year and believes she shall pay the loan in three months.

loans.use: Purchasing candies and sweets for selling sweet gifts for kids

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane M. is a 42 year old married mother of 6 children (ages 22, 18, 14, 14, 12, 10) who has a retail business and a piggery. She wants the loan to increase the stock in her retail store. From the profits she wants to build a residential house.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase her stock in her retail store

texts.en:
Naome K. is a 56 year old mother of 7 children (ages 25, 24, 22, 29, 27,9, 7) who operates a retail shop. She wants the loan to begin cash crop farming and start a business for her sons.

Gertrude N. is a 44 year old mother of 9 children (ages 24, 22, 20, 18, 16, 14, 12, 10, 8) and a fish monger. She wants the loan to purchase more stock and hopes to use the extra profits to open a retail store since the fish business is uncertain.

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma N. is a 30 year old married mother of 2 girls (ages 5 and 3) who sells charcoal. She wants the loan to begin a fresh food business and construct a stall for her businesses.

loans.use: To start a fresh food business

texts.en: Numon N. lives in Yova; he is married and has 5 children. Numon N. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006 and he is a serious and strongly motivated client.  At MLF Microinvest, loan amounts are increased for those who show business stability and increase their income. Numon has a business including the raising and selling of sheep as well as meat and sheep-hair production. He wants to purchase a pedigree ram for further sheep raising and meat production (it is supplied to bazaars). Mr.N. requests a loan of 3,100 TJS (US$900) for a pedigree ram purchase that allows him to significantly increase the family income and to further expand the business.

loans.name: Mahsudjon

texts.en: Mahsudjon M. lives in B.Gafurov. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 and recommends himself as a serious executive client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures. He is engaged in commercial services and trade. He is a taxi driver but is engaged in the business of selling meat products (salami, sausages, meat and other products). Mr. M. works in the Friday bazaar, where his shop is located. He is also engaged in fruit selling and has a wide assortment and permanent clients. Being a straight supplier, he has the opportunity to work with clients of different income levels. But working in the bazaar he has stiff competition, which is why he wants to widen the existing sales outlet.
