Ms Ngãi is 24 years old. She is married and has 1 daughter. She and her husband run a coffee shop in the town of Chờ for the last 6 years. Most of their clientele comes in the evening, especially during the weekend evenings. Their revenue from the coffee shop is stable. Before they have contracted a loan from the bank to expand their coffee shop. This time Ngãi has applied to BinhMinh fund (SEDA) for a loan to buy coffee, sugar, milk & cream for their coffee shop. She is eager to receive the loan and she will pay it back according to the loan term.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Ngãi 24 tuổi, chị đã có 1 con gái. Hai vợ chồng chị bán cafe và nước giải khát ở Phố Chờ được 6 năm. Quán nhà chị chủ yếu bán hàng vào buổi tối vì khách hàng thường đông nhất vào buổi tối và đặc biệt vào các tối cuối tuần. Thu nhập của gia đình chị khá ổn định. Trước kia để mở rộng quán, gia đình chị cũng vay vốn của ngân hàng. Lần này, chị vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh để phụ thêm vào mua cafe, đường, sữa cho công việc kinh doanh của chị. Chị rất mong sớm nhận được vốn vay và sẽ trả dần theo đúng thời hạn.

loans.use: To purchase stock for her coffee shop

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Pharn V., 46, is a mother of three children and lives in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and one of her children are employed by a private company as cleaners earning collectively about $4 each day, while her husband can typically make around $4/day in revenue from working as a mechanic. Mrs. Pharn Ry hopes the loan will help her purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Phan Vy and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

texts.en: Arzu has run this business for 5 years. This 32-year-old woman is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory. She lives in Fuzuli town and is settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region. She is single. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy goods to improve her business and get more income.

Sevda has been in animal sales for seven years. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region in Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs.

Sevda is 41 years old and married with three children. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy two calves to fatten for sale.

Minaya, born in 1958, is a mother of four children and an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town. Now she is settled in the Fuzuli region, in Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs.

Minaya (whose husband is pictured) has been in the dairy business for eight years. She has one cow. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy another cow, which will allow her to produce more milk and increase her business.

Tahir is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, in the Kurdmakhmudlu village. He was born in 1952; he is married and has four children.

Tahir buys calves to fatten for sale; he has been in this business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy two calves to improve his business.

Djavanshir was born in 1983. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in Fuzuli region, in the Kurdmakhmudlu village. A single man, Djavanshir has been as a taxi driver for two years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts.

Sakhavat is a single man who was born in 1985. He started his general store business five years ago. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the village of Garabag. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy goods to improve his business.

Ms. Vazifa is a 44-year-old woman. She is single and lives with her family in Saatli, situated in the central part of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 1990 when she purchased one cow with money she had saved up. The work is hard but interesting and takes a lot of effort. Vazifa purchases calves, breeds them, and sells them to the butcher, who works at the local big market. At the same time, the income is not enough to cover all of Vazifa’s family expenses. To increase her profit margin, Vazifa has to invest some money to make her small herd bigger. This summer, she applied for $800 to buy four calves. She hopes to expand her business eventually.

Ramila is a mother of one child. She was born in 1983. This woman is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town,  now settled in the Fuzuli region. Ramila's husband (pictured) has worked as a taxi driver for 5 years. Now they need a loan of $1200 to repair a car and improve their business.

Ms. Leyla is 53 year-old woman. She is married and lives in the village of Saatli town in the Azerbaijan Republic. 
She is a teacher in the local school. Her salary  is insufficient to support the family, and that's why Leyla has to run a business at home. She goes to the local bazaar, purchases calves, breeds them, and sells them to butchers. To increase her monthly turnover, Leyla applied for 800 USD from Norwegian Microcredit LLC, a KIVA partner.

Habil was born in 1965. He is married and has two children. Habil is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy the spare parts and improve his business.

Mohammad Ali lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has two sons. He lives with his own family. He has a retail shop in one of the crowded places of Kabul. He has a lot of clients. He would like to expand his business, so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his stock. He wants to make a good income to help his family and enroll his two sons in a good education center in Kabul. He is happy now.

Aftandil has been in the dairy business for 5 years. He was born in 1987, is married and has two children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. Now he would like to buy one cow for producing more milk.

loans.name: Hamid

texts.en:
Hamid is a married man with two children. He is a 54-year-old Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now living in Fuzuli town and settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region.

Hamid operates a general store and has been in this business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy goods for improving his business.

loans.use: to buy goods for his store

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en: “I love my small town, Vehari, that I have been living in for the past 15 years. I live in a mud and brick house with my husband and five children. My eldest boy and girl attend a school located in our local neighbourhood, while the rest of my children are too young to go to school. My husband requires a loan to purchase goats which we will sell over the Eid (a religious Muslim festival). During the Eid season, we will be able to sell the goats at a higher price. We took a loan last year for the same business and with the substantial profits we repaired our house, and we reinvested some of the profit in our business. We hope to do the same this year.”

loans.use: to purchase goats for re-sale for the Eid (Moslem holy day)

loans.name: Firdaus

texts.en: “Hello, I am Firdaus B. and have lived in Vehari all my life with my husband and one child. Our town is located about 350 km from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I want to expand my business of buying and selling bedding. My husband and I purchase bedding items from the city for US$ 6 and sell them for US$ 10 each in near-by villages. We have been doing this business for several years now and in order to expand we want to purchase bedding in bulk. Hence, we need a loan.  Moreover, the wedding season, during which we will sell more bedding, is right around the corner .”

loans.use: Purchase bed sheets to sell in near-by villages

loans.name: Saleema

texts.en: “I have lived all my life in Vehari, a small town located in the agricultural heart of Pakistan. I live in a brick house with my family, which consists of 12 members including myself. My husband and I have been running a bedding business for the last 10 years. We purchase sheets from manufacturers in bulk and re-sell them for a reasonable profit. We need a loan to purchase stock in bulk and thus save on costs. Also, since the Eid (traditional Muslim festival) is around the corner, we want to buy some goats, which we will sell at a high profit during the Eid, given the extra demand for them for the feast day. I am hoping that with the profits, I can get my daughters married off.”

loans.use: Purchase bed sheets in bulk for re-sale and goats to sell at the Eid

texts.en: Namig was born in 1981. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Finnish houses, which were built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region. Namig is married and has two children. He has run his clothing business for five years. Now he needs a loan of $850 to buy clothes, to help improve his business.

“I am Majeedan B. and have lived all my life in the small town of Vehari. I am married with four children. My husband and I have been running a bedding business for the past 12 years. We purchase bed sheets from large cities and sell door-to-door in our town and surrounding villages. We purchase each piece for US$ 4 and re-sell it for $9 to $10. We require a loan so that we can purchase bedding in bulk. Last year we took out a loan as well and reinvested the profits into our business. With the profits this year, I am hoping to have a doctor look at my father’s eyes. He's having trouble with his eyesight.”

loans.name: Sehnaz

texts.en: “I am Sehnaz B. and have lived in a rural area of Pakistan all my life. I have five children, four boys and one girl. Two of my children are in school, whereas the others are not of school-going age. My husband, Faiz Mohammad, and I run a business selling old and new sewing machines. We need to purchase spare parts for sewing machines and need a loan to do so. I would like to send my daughter to school but unfortunately our community does not allow girls to go to school. I am going to try to convince my husband this year to do that.”

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for sewing machines

loans.name: Amir

texts.en: “I am Amir M. and I moved to Vehari after I got married about three years ago. Now that my husband and I have a child, I have to help him generate income. I have the ability to sew clothes and can get work sewing for many small stores in town. I need a loan to purchase a sewing machine, thread, and some other materials so that I can establish my business. I used to sew before I got married but gave it up. Now I would like to pick it up again.”

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine and thread

loans.name: Manzooran

texts.en: “I have seven children and live in a small town called Vehari with my family, including my husband and seven children. I have five boys and two girls. My husband and I have been operating a bedding and bangles business for the past three years. We buy both bed sheets and bangles from the city in bulk and sell them at a profit door-to-door in our town and surrounding villages. We require a loan of US$ 150 to purchase stock in bulk. We purchase each piece for US$ 6 and sell for US$ 10 and believe that with the profits we will be able to return the loan.”

loans.use: Purchase stock of bedding and bangles to retail door-to-door

texts.en: Ms. Ghulbadam is a low-income vulnerable woman. She is 54, married with three children, and lives in the village of Saatli city in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Ghulbadam owns a small flock of sheep and some cows. Her son (he is pictured) assists her in selling sheep in the local bazaar. The business is going well but needs some improvement. Ghulbadam plans to increase the number of lambs she purchases to make her income higher. Her family expenditures are increasing as the children grow. Ghulbadam was approved to receive a $700 loan by the Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes this credit will allow her to change her family life.

loans.name: Parween

texts.en: “I live in a 2-room house in Vehari with my five children and my husband. I am grateful that all my children are in school and getting a reasonable education. While my nuclear family and I are ok, I would like to help out my brother so he can establish himself. He sells plastic toys and whistles to children in Vehari and wants to buy some in bulk. For this purpose he requires a loan. If you could help us, I would be grateful.”

loans.use: Purchase plastic toys and whistles for re-sale

texts.en: Rasim was born in 1959. He has been in the dairy business for seven years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region, in Kayidish village, which was built for IDPs. Rasim is married and has three children. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy a cow to help improve his business.

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: “I live in a four-room house with my three children and husband. We live in a relatively rural area in the agricultural heartland of Pakistan. I run a small store right next to my house and want to add a few items to it. Since we have electricity in our town, I would like to purchase a fridge to store soft drinks and ice creams, etc. I would also like to add a telephone call office so that people from the neighbourhood can come and place phone calls (they would pay to call). I think the call office will bring in good business. With the remaining money, I will purchase some stock for my store. These are the reasons I require a loan."

loans.use: Install a call office at the general store and purchase a freezer for ice cream

loans.name: Khurshida

texts.en: “I live in a three-room house with my husband and nine children in a small town called Vehari, about four hours away from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. Most of our children are small. My husband makes special bed sheets with his hand loom. These sheets are semi-thick and good for spring and fall season. However, his hand loom is old and needs refurbishing. He requires a loan to fix his hand loom and purchase spare parts along with some thread. Since there is plenty of demand for our bed sheets, I am confident that he will make a profit.”

loans.use: Repair hand loom used for making special bed sheets

texts.en: “I live in the small town of Vehari which lies near the cotton belt of Pakistan. My husband and I, along with our four children, live in a two-room house. My husband has a fruit cart and wants to purchase seasonal fruits in bulk for re-sale in our town. With a loan, he will be able to sell bananas, apples, grapes, and pomegranates. Our business is now pretty successful since last year we took out a loan and were able to reinvest the profits in our business and also send our children to school. This year we hope to do the same. I also help my husband by stitching clothes for women and children in our neighbourhood.”

loans.name: Haseena

texts.en: “I live in Vehari in one room with my husband and eight children. Since Vehari is a small town in Pakistan we lead a simple life and, for example, in the summer we sleep outdoors. We all try to pitch in to generate income for the family. My husband trades goats and sheep while I sell blankets and rugs in the winter, door-to-door. Right now my husband needs a loan to buy goats and sheep and sell them at a profit once they are older. Hopefully we will make enough money one day to send our children to school.”

loans.use: Purchase goats and sheep to raise and re-sell at a profit

texts.en: Ms. Minaya is a 34-year-old woman. She lives with her family in the village of Saatli city, which is situated in the central part of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 2002 when she purchased one cow with money she had saved up. Since then, Minaya collected up to seven cows. She buys calves, breeds them, and sells them to the butcher, who works in the local big market. Minaya has collected enough customers and needs to increase the number of animals in her herd. This project requires investment. For this purpose, Minaya applied for a $1000 loan to buy five calves from Normicro.  She hopes to expand her business eventually.

“I have four children and live in a small town very near the historic city of Multan in Pakistan. I live in a three-room house with my husband and four children. My husband and I need a loan for our bicycle and motorcycle rental business. We are hoping to purchase several bicycles this time.

Besides the rental business, my husband also runs a barber shop to generate sufficient income for our family's needs. Last year, too, we took out a loan for the rental business and with the profits we made, we purchased some much needed household items."

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en: “I have two children and live in a small town called Vehari with my family. Our town is located about 350 km from the second largest city in Pakistan, Lahore . Since our town is so far from the city, it is difficult for people to obtain the most basic medicines. We provide a much-needed service and sell basic medicines for colds, fevers, and flus. We need a loan to purchase medicines in bulk so that we can make a reasonable profit by saving on the costs.”

loans.use: Purchase medicines to re-sell to people in my neighborhood

loans.name: Janat

texts.en: “I am fifty years old and have one child. My family and I live in a two-room house in the agricultural belt of Pakistan. One of my sons died a few years back and left a daughter. I have to help my daughter-in-law take care of this grand-daughter. Since I prefer working from home, I run a livestock business so that I do not have to go out much except to the market. I need a loan so that I can purchase a cow ro raise and sell later at a higher price, when the cow is strong enough.”

loans.use: Purchase a cow to raise and sell later at a higher price

texts.en: “I am Sabran B. and live in the small town of Vehari in Pakistan. I require a loan for my own jewellery business. I sell jewellery door-to-door and in villages surrounding Vehari. I purchase my jewellery, which includes traditional bangles, from Multan and Lahore, two large cities. Fortunately, my husband and I make  enough to feed our five children.”

Makhira is the mother of two children. She has been in the clothing sales business for five years. This 33-year-old woman is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region, in Bala Bakhmanli village, which was built for IDPs. Now Makhira needs a loan of $725 to buy clothes to help improve her business.

Ms. Ghuleela is a low-income vulnerable woman. She is 43, married with three children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the the Caucasus region. Ghuleela has a scanty herd of milk cows and sells 60 liters of milk per day to the local milk processing shop and to the supermarket. The trade is good and Ghuleela can see that she could sell more milk. This requires more cattle in her herd. Ghuleela decided to buy a milk cow to increase her monthly turnover. She applied for a $1000 loan from the Normicro Saatli branch to buy a cow and increase the number of cattle in her herd.

Nazli is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region, in Bala Bakhmanli village. She was born in 1962. She is married and has three children. Ten years ago she started her clothing sales business. Now she needs a loan of $725 to buy clothes to improve her business.

loans.name: Jurahon

texts.ru:
Jurahon H., who is 48, is a graduate of college with specialization of an accountant-statistician. He has 7 children. Currently, he is employed by the city of Yavan as an accountant. Using funds from the loan, he is planning to purchase additional cattle for breeding and later sales. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. This allows him to have an additional source of income, which helps them to support his big family, because his earnings from the city are not sufficient to last a whole month. At the end of the loan term, Jurahon will have 3 breeds of cattle as his profit. He is planning to repay his loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Холов Джурахон, возраст – 48 лет, образование среднее-техническое, по специальности бухгалтер – статистик, женат, имеет 7-х детей. В настоящее время Джурахон работает в Электрических сетях города Явана, в должности бухгалтера. На полученный кредит клиент хочет приобрести 2 головы крупного рогатого скота для их откормки и продажи. Этим видом деятельности клиент занимается уже в течение 10 лет. Это позволяет иметь ему дополнительный источник дохода, который помогает содержать большую семью, так как зарплаты не хватает на целый месяц. В конце кредитного цикла клиенту в качестве прибыли останется 3 головы молодняка. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of two cows for breeding and later sales

texts.en: Zarina (her sister is pictured) is the mother of one child. She was born in 1989. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region, in Bala Bakhmanli village. Five years ago she started her clothing sales business. Now she needs a loan of $725 to buy clothes to improve her business.

Valentina (her husband is pictured) was born in 1948. She is the mother of three children. Valentina is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region in Kayidish village, which was built for IDPs. Ten years ago her family started their cattle-breeding business. Now they need a loan of $600 to buy one calf to improve their business.

Ms. Nazaket is a low-income vulnerable woman. She is 42, married with three children, and lives in the village of Saatli city in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Nazaket owns a small herd of milk cows. She sells milk in the Saatli bazaar. Her family expenditures are increasing as her children grow. Nazaket plans to increase her number of cattle to make her income higher. This project requires investment. This winter, Nazaket applied for a $1000 loan from the Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes this credit will allow her to change her family life.

loans.name: Nanda Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Nanda Kumari M., 24 years old, lives in Thecho, Laltipur, Nepal. Most of the people in this area are engaged in agricultural work. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband, one son, and one daughter. Her husband's name is Daya Ram M.. He works in a carpet factory. Her daughter is studying in grade 2.

Mrs. M. opened her tailor shop 2 months ago. Before that, she worked in her friend’s tailor shop. She makes different types of ladies' dresses in her shop. She prefers to make traditional and modern dresses for ladies like blouses and kurta Sulwar.

Now she is asking for her first loan of in the amount of US$ 175 to buy cloth, shears, etc. for her new tailor shop. She wants to earn enough to be able to spend her income on her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy cloth etc. for her tailor shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

texts.en: Aladdin was born in 1969. He is married and has three children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region. He has run his cattle-breeding business for five years. Now he needs a loan of $600 to buy one calf.

Mrs. Ratna Devi M., 36 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district, Nepal. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children. Her husband, Mr. Bhai Gopal M., works in a furniture manufacturing shop. Her son is studying in grade 12. Her older daughter is studying in grade 10 and her younger daughter is studying in grade 4.

Mrs. M. is a cotton weaver, weaving in her own house. She has been doing her work for 18 years. She took 6 months training for her work from Small Cottage Industries near her area. She makes dresses to order out of the material she weaves. Now she is requesting her second loan of US$ 250 to buy thread for weaving and also to repair her loom.

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en:
Mrs. Nirmala M., 32 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district, Nepal. Thecho is one of the backward areas of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 7 and the younger son is studying in grade 4.

Her husband's name is Tari Babu M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture-making shop 7 years ago. All the requirements of their family must be met by the shop income. Therefore Mrs. M. is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 175 to buy timber so as to be able to fill their orders for furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture such as beds, tables, chairs, and wardrobes.

loans.use: to buy timber for a carpentry shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Chini Devi

texts.en:
Mrs. Chini Devi M., 40 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district, Nepal. Thecho is one of the developing village of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband, one son, and one daughter. Her daughter and son are studying in grades 9 and 8 respectively.
Her husband, Mr. Gopal M., is a plumber. Her husband’s work is the only source of family income. For his work he needs various types of tools and other raw materials. So Mrs. M. is requesting her first loan of US$ 175 to help her husband to buy modern tools for his work. She will be very grateful if this first loan through Kiva is granted to her.

loans.use: To buy modern tools for her husband's plumbing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

texts.en: Asif was born in 1973. He is married and has two children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region. Ten years ago, he started his taxi-driving business. Now he needs a loan of  $475 to buy spare parts to help improve his business.

loans.name: Sarswati

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarswati M., 35 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho village is famous for agriculture and farming. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband, two sons, and a daughter. Her daughter left school and now works in a carpet factory. Her sons are studying in grades 10 and 7 respectively.

Her husband's name is Kazi Babu M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture shop 7 years ago. All the requirements of the family are supplied from the shop income. Therefore Mrs. M. is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 175 to buy timber so that they can fill all their orders for furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture such as beds, tables, and chairs, and also windows and doors .

loans.use: To buy timber for their carpentry workshop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

texts.en: Zahir has been in the cattle-breeding business for five years. He was born in 1975. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan and is settled in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has two children. Now he needs a loan of $475 to buy a calf.

Djamafar (her sister is pictured) is the mother of one child. She was born in 1953 and lives in Khachmaz town. She has been in the business of cattle breeding for a year. Now Djamafar needs a loan of $1,200 to buy a cow in order to improve her business.

texts.vi:
Ms Võ Thị Hảo, 56, lives in Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An with her husband and 2 children. Her older 4 children are grown up, some have their own family some are working far away from home. Before joining TYM, her family living condition was difficult. Her first loan with TYM was used to cultivate vegetables which was a familiar work for her. Her income from selling vegetables was enough to cover her family living expenses. With time her loans were raised, these were used effectively so her income had raised as well. Selling the vegetables brings her 2.5 USD a day. Her monthly income is on average 70 USD. This time she is requesting a loan of 325 USD to buy seeds and manure.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Võ Thị Hảo, 56 tuổi, sống cùng với chồng và 2 người con tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An. Bốn người con lớn của chị đều đã trưởng thành, người có gia đình, người đi làm xa. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị hết sức khó khăn. Từ 30USD vốn vay đầu tiên chị chọn công việc gần gũi với bản thân là trồng rau vặt. Mức thu nhập từ công việc này đủ để chị Hảo trang trải những khoản chi phí nhỏ trong gia đình. Dần dần mức vốn vay được tăng lên, biết cách sử dụng đồng vốn có hiệu quả, lượng rau bán ra hàng ngày mang lại thu nhập cho chị Hảo 2,5USD, trung bình một tháng thu nhập là 70USD. Dự kiến trong thời gian tới chị xin vay 325USD để mua giống và phân bón.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Hồng is 25 years old. She participates in TYM fund since 2001. When she first joined TYM, she just got married and so she was going through financial difficulty. Her first loan was 50 USD which was invested in pig raising. After a few years, her loan limit had raised and so did her revenue. She now has acquired a lot of experience in farming. This time she is requesting a loan of 825 USD to buy pigs, chickens, ducks and feed to expand her farming business. Her monthly income is 125 USD. She is living in Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An with her husband and 2 children.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng, 25 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2001. Khi tham gia vào Quỹ, chị vừa mới kết hôn nên kinh tế gia đình lúc đó còn nhiều eo hẹp. Chị chủ động tham gia vay vốn với mức vay đầu tiên là 50USD đầu tư vào chăn nuôi nhỏ. Kết quả thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và đồng vốn vay của chị Hồng tăng dần qua các năm tham gia. Với những kinh nghiệm tích lũy được trong chăn nuôi chị dự đinh xin vay 825USD mua thêm lợn, gà vịt cùng thức ăn gia súc để mở rộng chăn nuôi. Mức thu nhập hiện tại của chị Hồng là 125USD/tháng. Chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng và hai con nhỏ tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An.

loans.use: Buy pigs, chickens, ducks and mash

loans.name: Doan Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Doãn Thị Tuyết, 54, joined TYM fund in 2001. Her first loan was 60 USD which was invested in poultry raising. She was also selling basic goods like eggs, garlic, onion ...etc. Her daily income was about 2-3 USD, combined with her husband salary she was able to cover the family expenses and put away some savings. In her 3rd year with TYM, she used the loan and her savings to expand her poultry business. She now has a flock of 30 egg laying chickens, this brings in 100 USD a month. She is applying for a loan of 625 USD to buy some pigs and chicken feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2001, chị Doãn Thị Tuyết, 54 tuổi, vay mức vay đầu tiên là 60USD. Với số tiền này chị đã đầu tư vào nuôi gà đẻ và buôn bán các mặt hàng như trứng gà, hành, tỏi v.v... Số tiền lãi thu được hàng ngày khoảng từ 2-3USD đủ để chị bớt đi những lo toan về kinh tế. Cộng với số lương hưu của chồng, ngoài các khoản chi tiêu hàng tháng, chị cũng tích lũy được thêm ít nhiều. Cộng với đồng vốn vay từ năm thứ 3 chị đã đầu tư vào mở rộng chăn nuôi. Đàn gà hiện nay của chị Tuyết khoảng 30 con mang lại cho chị thu nhập 100USD/tháng. Chị đang làm hồ sơ xin vay 625USD để mua thêm vài con lợn cùng thức ăn cho đàn gà của mình.

loans.use: Buy pigs, mash and chicken feed

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Mrs. Say M., 31, is a widow and runs a hairdressing stand at a busy market. She typically makes around $5 each day. She doesn’t have any children living with her since she is divorced from her husband. One reason Mrs. Say M. is happy with her business is because she is able to meet a lot of people. She is currently applying for a loan to purchase more hairdressing tools and make-up products to meet her growing customer demands.

loans.use: To purchase more hairdressing tools and make-up products to meet her growing customer demands

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheng D., 37, works as a housewife, while her husband and her oldest son can collectively make only about US$ 2 each day from working as construction workers. The big expense for Mrs. Cheng D.’s family is supporting her other five school-going children. Day to day, she has concerns about her family’s income generation and she would like to raise her family's standard of living.

Mrs. Cheng D. has recently requested a loan in the amount of US$ 1000 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to use to operate a motor-taxi. With a new motor-bike, she believes they will have more income which will enable her and her family to raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to use to operate a motor-taxi

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Mrs. Morn N.,37, works with her husband selling porridge and noodle soup to the people in their community, making collectively around US$ 10/day in revenue. She has three children living with her. One of them works as a carpenter and the other two are enrolled in school. Morn N. hopes to use this loan to invest her and her husband's business and also to buy carpentry tools for her son to facilitate his work.

loans.use: To invest in her business and also buy carpentry tools for her son

loans.name: Mohammad Salim

texts.en: Mohammad Salim lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and he lives with his own family. He has a clothing shop. He is a hard-working and energetic man. For more than 5 years, he has operated a store in Kabul where he sells men’s and women’s clothing. During this time, he attracted a lot of clients. Now he wants to expand his business, so he requested an individual loan to buy new designs of clothes to make a good income and help his family. He is happy with all parts of his family.

loans.use: To buy new designs of clothes

loans.name: Mussarat

texts.en: Mussarat B. is from Lahore, a historical city in Pakistan. Her husband operates a fruit and vegetable sales business in the city's food market. Mussarat is a mother of two sons and two daughters. One of her sons is handicapped, while the others all study at a local school. She wishes her children a bright and healthy future. Curently, however, Mussarat needs a loan of US$200 to help her husband buy fruit in bulk for sale. With the help of the loan, she and her family hope to increase their income and later on be able to buy a house of their own.

loans.use: Purchase of fruit in bulk for sale

texts.en: Kafia S. is married and a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. Currently, one of her children attends school, while the others are still too young. Kafia is determined to educate her children, because, although she is not much educated herself, she is aware of the importance of good education. Kafia's husband is a welder and currently needs a loan to help expand his business and be able to take on orders of a larger scale.

Shahnaz I. has been married for 28 years and has five children: three sons and two daughters. She lives with her family in a brick house in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. Her husband earns money making marble stones for graves. Marble is very expensive, and, therefore, Shahnaz is asking for a loan of US$175 to buy marble in a sufficient quantity for her husband to be able to continue his work. She has once before taken a loan at a very high interest rate from a local money lender, and yet managed to pay it back. Shahnaz hopes that she will receive a loan this time as well.

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: I am Shazia N. from Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan.  I am a mother of six: four boys and two girls. My husband is a rickshaw driver and a welder; he drives rickshaw in the evening and welds in the morning on order. He needs a loan to buy few welding tools and also repair his rickshaw. My husband works very hard so that he can provide food and clothing for us.

loans.use: Buy welding tools and repair rickshaw

loans.name: Yasmeen

texts.en: I am Yasmeen Z.. I am married and a mother of two: one son and one daughter. I live with my family in my hometown Lahore, Pakistan. My daughter has completed her college and currently she is teaching at a local school whereas my son is in grade ten. My husband has a heart problem and therefore cannot work and I stitch bed sheets to earn a living. I need a loan of $175 to expand my business.

loans.use: Need loan to expand bed sheets business and buy cloth

texts.en: I am Asma A. from a big city Lahore, Pakistan. I am married and a mother of a girl who is seven months old. We live in a three room brick house. My husband fixes marble on graves and now he needs a loan of $175 to buy marble for his business.

My name is Naseem P.. I belong to Lahore, a historical city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. I and my husband both sell video cassettes and audio cassettes in various cities on different festivals. I need a loan of $175 to buy cassettes in bulk for the New Year festival.

I request a loan of $175 for my husband’s grocery store. He needs this loan to buy necessary items for his store that are out of stock. I am a mother of an only girl who studies in grade five. We are both very hopeful to give our daughter a bright future.

loans.name: Yun

texts.en: Mrs. Yun Y., 39, is the mother of four children and works selling flowers at an open-air market, earning typically around US$ 3/day in revenue. Her husband is self-employed as a construction foreman and makes about US$ 5 per day. Mrs. Yun Y. hopes to use this loan to invest in her flower business and to purchase a motorcycle to use for her business as transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use for her business as transportation

texts.en: My husband is a designer and he carves jewelry out of gold and silver. It is our family business. Few years ago my husband grew very ill and his business suffered badly. Thankfully now he has regained health and requires a loan of$175 to buy silver for his business. We have ten kids: seven boys and three girls. I embroider clothes to support my family.

I am Tahira Z. from a big city Lahore, Pakistan. I live here with my husband and four kids in a brick house. My husband gives pick and drop services to the students at a local school in the morning and afternoon, and in the evening operates a mobile phones shop. He also offers repairing services at his store. Now he needs to buy a few  mobile phone accessories for his store for which he needs a loan of $175.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 42-year-old father of 4. He lives with his family in the Beirut suburbs. Hussein sells vegetables to the neighboring inhabitants. He is the sole provider for his 4 children. Hussein needs to develop his business and respond to the clients' demands. He therefore wants to buy more provisions in order to sustain his commerce.

loans.use: To buy expanded inventory for his little vegetable stand

texts.en: I am Basheeran S.. I am married and a mother of three sons. My husband fixes marble on graves and I go door to door selling rice and bed sheets. I have been in this business for the past two years and by now I have many clients. I need a loan of $175 to expand my business further and buy a stock of rice. Your loan will help me continue to improve my business and hence my household income.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 23-year-old married man. He lives with his family in the Beirut suburbs. Mohamad is a butcher. He needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy more meat for his butcher shop in order to generate additional revenue to continue his house payments. This is the second time Mohamad is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua. He is a hard-working and reliable young man.

loans.use: To buy more meat to sell in his butcher shop

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru:
Rustam I., who is 29, is married and has 1 child. Rustam is in the business of selling VHS and DVDs in the market "Sabrina" in the town of Yavan. Also, Rustam edits videos of weddings and other various events recorded on VHS. Using the loan, he plans to purchase blank DVDs, VCR, DVR, and other necessary equipment. This credit will give people living in the town an opportunity to obtain edited videos of celebrations and other events. Rustam is panning to pay off the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Ибодов Рустам, возраст – 29 лет, образование среднее, женат, имеет 1 ребенка. Рустам занимается продажей видеокассет и DVD – дисков в торговом центре под названием «Сабрина» в городе Явана. Также Рустам занимается видеомонтажем дней рождений, свадебных торжеств и других мероприятий записанных на видеокассеты. На полученный кредит клиент планирует приобрести DVD-диски, видеомагнитофон и другое оборудование необходимое для этой деятельности. Данный кредит даст возможность жителям данного района производить видеомонтаж снятых на видео торжественных мероприятий. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 15 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of equipment for video editing and recording on CDs

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 50-year-old father of 11. He lives with his family in the Beirut suburbs. Mohamad owns a store where he sells chickens. This is the 8th time Mohamad is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua. He wants to buy more chickens in order to generate additional revenues to help his son open his own business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for re-sale in his little store

texts.en: Viviane is a 25-year-old young woman. Viviane owns a clothing store, and she needs to purchase new merchandise for her business. This is the 3rd time Viviane has asked for a loan from A. Majmoua. Viviane is an independent and ambitious micro-entrepreneur.

Viviane is a 25 years old young woman. Viviane owns a clothing store and she needs to purchase new merchandise for her business. This is the 3rd time Viviane is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. Viviane is an independent and ambitious micro entrepreneur.

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: Mrs. Tes D., 39, is the mother of four children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works selling a wide variety of grocery products to the people in her area, earning on average around US$ 7 each day in revenue. Her husband is currently unemployed, while one of her children works as a construction worker and another one is enrolled in school. In order to generate more income, Mrs. Tes D. would like to purchase a car for her husband to use to operate a taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a car for her husband to use as a taxi to generate more income for her family

texts.en: I am a widow Shazia J.. I have four small children one of whom is handicapped.  I have some how managed to send other three to school. I sew clothes for my neighborhood women and now I need a loan of $175. I plan to invest this loan in my brother’s workshop who in return will give me a suitable rate of return. I am in a great need to increase my income so that I can continue ending my children to school.

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en: Abbass is a 36-year-old father of 6. He lives with his family in the Beirut suburbs. Abbass is a mechanic who fixes vehicles and sells auto parts. This is the 5th time Abbass is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua. He wants to buy new auto parts to continue sustaining and developing his business.

loans.use: To buy auto parts to use in repairing cars and for re-sale

texts.ru:
Ashur D. is 56 and has a secondary school education. He is married with six children. Rustam has been breeding livestock for four years and this is his main source of income. He plans to use his loan to purchase two young bulls to fatten and sell. After he sells them, in 40-45 he will buy more young animals to raise and sell over ten months. At the end of the credit cycle he will retain three bulls as profit. Ashur plans to repay his loan over a ten month period.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Дониев Ашур, возраст – 56 лет, образование среднее, женат, имеет 6-х детей. Ашур в течение 4 лет занимается разведением крупного рогатого скота и этот вид деятельности является основным источником приносящий ему доход. Он планирует на сумму кредита приобретсти 2 бычков для откормки и продажи. Продавать бычков клиент собирается через 40-45дней после откормки. Затем он будет покупать молодняк, откармливать и опять продавать, и так в течение 10 месяцев. В конце кредитного цикла ему в качестве прибыли, согласно подготовленного прогноза должно остаться 3 бычка. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 10 месяцев.

Ali A. is 62 years old and has a secondary school education. He is married and has seven children. Rustam has been breeding livestock for three years and this is his main source of income. He plans to use his loan to buy two young bulls to raise and sell. After he sells them in 40-45 he will buy more young animals to fatten and sell over ten months. At the end of the credit cycle, he will retain three bulls as profit. He plans to repay his loan within a ten month period.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Азизов Али, возраст – 62 года, образование среднее, женат, имеет 7-х детей. Али в течение 3 лет занимается разведением крупного рогатого скота и этот вид деятельности является основным источником приносящий ему доход. Он планирует на сумму кредита приобретсти 2 бычков для откормки и продажи. Продавать бычков он будет через 40-45 дней после откормки, затем он будет покупать новый молодняк, откармливать и опять продавать, и так в течение 10 месяцев. В конце кредитного цикла ему в качестве прибыли, согласно подготовленного прогноза должно остаться 3 бычка. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 10 месяцев.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Mrs. Lun H., 47, is married with six children and works as a housewife, cleaning and cooking food for her entire family, while her husband is employed as a soldier, earning US$ 2 each day. Some of her children work as security guards; some work at a factory, and one is a student.

Mrs. Lun H. would like to open a laundry to generate additional income for her family, but she faces financial constraints. She would like to request a loan to purchase a washing machine to use to operate her business so as to improve their financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase a washing machine to use to operate a laundry business

texts.en: I am Sonia M.. I am married and a mother of three: two boys and one girl. All of kids study at a local school. My husband sells LPG gas cylinders on partnership basis in a nearby gas store. He is able to sell eight cylinders daily. He needs a loan of $175 to expand his business. We both husband and wife are determined to educate our children to a maximum so that they can find better employment for themselves and do not have to do menial jobs.

texts.ru:
Mahmadnazar H. is 36 and has a higher education in music. He is married with four children. Mahmadnazar works in a music conservatory. He also provides his services as a wedding singer in the area. He plans to use his loan to renovate his musical equipment and obtain some necessary spare parts. In wedding season there are ceremonies almost every day. Now newlyweds will have the chance to hire Mahmadnazar for a moderate price, instead of turning to artists from other regions, who charge higher prices due to transport costs. Mahmadnazar plans to repay his loan over a 12-month period.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Халимов Махмадназар, возраст – 36 ktn, образование высшее - музыкальное, женат, имеет 4-х детей. Махмадназар в настоящее время работает в музыкальной консерватории. Также она оказывает услуги певца на свадьбах, которрые проводятся в этом и близлежащих районах. Полученный кредит он хочет использовать на обновление своей музыкальной аппаратуры и приобретение необходимых запчастей к ним. Так как в сезон свадеб они проводятся почти каждый день, молодожены получат возможносьт приглашать его на свою свадьбу по умеренной цене, не приглашая артистов из других районов, которые предоставляют свои услуги по более высоким ценам, так как они включают туда и транспортные расходы. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Mrs. Chuon S., 24, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works with her husband at a garment factory, earning collectively around US$ 5 to $6 each day. Mrs. Chuon S. would like to request a loan to purchase a sewing machine and cloth so she can open a tailoring business at home. Part of the loan money will also be used to buy a motorcycle for her family’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and cloth so she can open a tailoring business at home

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en: I am Sumaira M. from Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of four: three daughters and one son. My husband works at a theatre for a small pay and I stitch clothes on order from my neighborhood clients. I sew so that my children can attend good school. I need a loan of $175 to buy a latest sewing machine for my business.

loans.use: Buy a sewing machine for the business

texts.ru:
Malika S. is 34. She has a secondary school education and is married with four children. For four years, Malika has been selling Tajik national textiles, which are used to make women's clothes. She has a trading point at one of the markets in Tursun-zoda. With her loan, she plans to buy a new assortment of fabric. This will give local women the chance to obtain the cloth needed to sew their national costumes. There is a demand for this among the local population. Malika plans to repay her loan over a 12-month period.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Шодиева Малика, возраст – 34 года, образование среднее, замужем, имеет 4-х детей. Малика уже в течение 4 лет занимается продажей женских национальных тканей для пошива одежды, для этого она имеет торговую точку на одном из рынков города Турсунзаде. На полученный кредит она планирует приобрести новый ассортимент женских тканей. Это даст возможность местным женщинам приобретать необходимые ткани для пошива женской национальной одежды, пользующуюся спросом у местного населения. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.name: Saima

texts.en: I am Saima T. from the second big city in Pakistan, Lahore. I am married and a mother of two sons. My elder son is in kindergarten, whereas the other is only one and a half years old and therefore does not attend school. We live here in Lahore in a three-room mud brick house.My husband is a welder and needs a loan of $350 for his welding shop. He intends to buy a grinder, a drill machine and a new welding plant with your loan.

loans.use: Buy welding machine, drill machine and a grinder for the business

loans.name: Anwer

texts.en: I am Anwer B.. I was married 27 years ago and live with my family in Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. I have three kids: two sons and one daughter. I sew clothes on order from my neighborhood clients, and my husband runs a grocery store. We need a loan of $350 to buy plastic bowls and plates for our store; it is because our customers always demand them. We hope this addition will turn into higher profits, which I will save to repair my house.

loans.use: Buy plastic bowls and plates for the store

texts.en: I am Allah R.. I live in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married with five children: three sons and two daughters. Two of them are done with their studies and are currently working, while the others attend school. I work at someone’s house as a maid, and my husband operates a fruit cart. Now we require a loan of $350 to add new varieties of fruit to our cart. Earlier we took loans for this business, which turned into better profits.

My name is Munnawer A.. I am a mother of eight: four sons and four daughters. All of my children could not get an education due to our poor financial circumstances. I embroider clothes on order, and two of my sons are apprentices at a welder’s shop. By now they have gained enough expertise and therefore want to start their own business. We therefore require a loan of $175 for this purpose.

I request a loan of $175 for my husband, who is a welder. He needs this loan to buy items such as welding machines and drills, etc. I am a mother of five: four daughters and one son. I am not educated, but I do not want the same fate to befall my kids, therefore I send them to school except the youngest two, who are not of school-going age yet.

I am Nusrat K.. I am married and a mother of six: four sons and two daughters. My husband works at a government institute for low pay, and I embroider clothes on order. One of my sons has started a furniture business and he is in the process of expanding it, for which he needs a loan as assistance. It is very hot here in summer, therefore my son has promised to buy us a fridge when his income will increase.

I am Razia B. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I live here in a two-room brick house. I am a mother of five: four boys and one daughter. Three of my kids currently attend school, whereas the others are not of school-going age yet. I sew clothes for the women in my neighborhood, and my husband runs a clothes shop. His shop does well, and now he needs to expand his business. Therefore, he requires a loan of $175 for this purpose.

I am Razia T. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I was born in Faisalabad but moved to Lahore after my marriage 15 years ago. I have eight kids: two daughters and six sons. I embroider clothes for my neighborhood clients. Three of my sons operate a fruit business, and now they require a loan of $350 to expand their business. We plan to buy a fridge this year from the extra profits.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: I am Nasreen S.. I am married and a mother of six: five girls and one son. All of them attend school except the youngest, who is not of school-going age yet. I embroider clothes on order and my husband runs an irons business. He paints the body of these irons. Now he requires a loan of $175 to buy paints in bulk for the business.

loans.use: Buy paint in bulk for the business

loans.name: Mumtaz

texts.en: I am Mumtaz S.. I am married and a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. Currently, only my eldest girl attends school, while the others are small and do not attend school. I embroider clothes and my husband is a tailor. Now my husband needs to buy  two sewing machines, one for himself and one for the worker that he has hired for his shop. Please lend us $175 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy sewing machines for the business

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ablavi A. was born in 1958 in Bè. She is married and is the mother of 8 children. Her husband is jobless and somewhat elderly, so he is not able to support his family. Selling tooth picks as a street peddlar is the business activity that brings in the meager income the family lives off of.

Faced with this situation, Mrs. A. is requesting a loan of US$ 200 so that she can purchase in larger quantities and become a wholesaler of tooth picks. Being able to do this will increase her income, since it is a flourishing business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mme Ablavi A. est née en 1958 à Bè. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants, son mari est chômeur et il est un peu âgé donc il n’arrive pas à supporter toutes les charges du ménage. Le commerce de cuire dent est son activité qui lui procure le peu de revenu pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

>Devant cette situation, elle sollicite un montant de $200 pour s’approvisionner en quantité de cuire dent et devenue grossiste. La réalisation de ce projet augmentera ses revenus car c’est un commerce très florissant.

loans.use:
Sale of tooth picks

Approvisionnement en cuir dent

loans.name: Enayat

texts.en: I am Enayat B. from a historical city in Pakistan, Lahore. I am a mother of nine: four sons and five daughters. My husband is a scrap dealer and I run a grocery store. I have made a store in my house to serve my neighborhood clients. I need a loan of $250 to buy some required items such as sugar, oil, flour, etc. for my store. I hope to generate good profits from my store.

loans.use: Buy items for her grocery store

texts.en: I am Bushra P. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I was born and brought up in the small city of Jhang but moved to Lahore after my marriage. I am a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. Three of my kids at present attend school, and one is small and does not go to school.  My husband is in construction, and he needs a loan to expand his business.

loans.name: Ghazala

texts.en: I am 30, married and a mother of four: two boys and two girls. I live with my family in the second largest city of Pakistan—Lahore. My husband is a carpenter, and he manufactures very beautiful furniture out of wood.  We have previously acquired a few loans for this business, which translated into increased income. I stay at home, and along with my household chores, I make comforters for my neighborhood clients. Now my husband requires another loan of $350 to invest in his business and buy wood in a large quantity.

loans.use: Needs a loan to buy wood

texts.en: I am Rubina R. from Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. I am 38, married and a mother of seven. I make plastic flowers on daily wages, and my husband is a carpenter. Last year we took a loan to buy an electric saw for our business, which turned into greater efficiency. But this time I require a loan to start my own business of plastic flowers. I am sure the business will do well because I have enough skill and experience in it.

loans.name: Gentille

texts.fr:
Mrs. Gentille E. was born in 1955 in Agoè. A widow with four children of her own, she also has two other orphans for whom she is responsible. She sells condiments (hot peppers, tomatoes, onions, etc.) and this is the only source of income permitting her to support her family. The business earns well but Mrs. E. does not have enough capital to purchase the goods she sells wholesale and thus make her business more profitable. She is requesting a loan of US$ 800 for that purpose. This will allow her to satisfy her customers' needs and make a bit more profit to support her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame Gentille E. est née en 1955 à Agoè. Veuve avec quatre (4) enfants, elle a à sa charge deux (2) autres orphelins. La vente des condiments (piments, tomate, oignons, etc.) reste sa seule source de revenue qui lui permet de subvenir aux charges familiales. C’est un commerce très rentable mais les moyens de Madame E. son très insuffisants pour plus rentabiliser son activité. Elle sollicite un financement de $800 pour acheter en gros les condiments afin de satisfaire sa clientèle et avoir un peu plus de bénéfice pour pouvoir supporter ses enfants.

loans.use:
Wholesale purchase of condiments

Stockage de condiments

texts.en: It is the first time that I am acquiring a loan. I require this loan for my husband’s small shoe factory. I am a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. Currently, only three of my kids attend school, whereas the fourth one is too small to attend school. Whenever I get time away from my household chores I stitch clothes for the women in my area.

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.en:
‘Pinchón’ – as she is affectionately called by her friends and neighbors – is a hyperactive, strong, and hard-working woman. She is thirty-three years old and she has three children. To earn a living and take care of her children, she sells pants, blue jeans, and underwear to women of her community.

Her contagious laugh, her kindness toward the customers, and her ‘crazy’ jokes help her cultivate good relations with people, keeping the present customers loyal and attracting new ones.

Eusebia explains that she would like to rent a locale before long so that she can run her business more easily. With her loan, she will buy clothing in bulk in Santo Domingo, the capital. That way, Eusebia will reduce the frequent trips outside her community to get goods. She will increase her income and keep working for the sake of her family.

loans.use: Purchase clothing in bulk for her small business

loans.name: Leonor De Rosario

texts.en:
Leonor is thirty-six years old, and she and her husband have four children, three of them boys, that go to the public school in their community. Three years ago, Leonor started a small business, selling beauty products and women’s clothing and sneakers. In the morning, after preparing meals for the children, Leonor goes down to the streets to sell her goods. In the afternoon, people visit her home to purchase garments. Currently, that activity is the principal source of income of the family.

The entrepreneur hopes that her business can keep growing and that she can get more clients. With her loan, she will buy clothing in bulk outside her community, in a frontier city with Haiti, where garments can be obtained at low prices. That way, Leonor can increase her income and profits.

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of clothing in bulk to keep on running her business

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is in her early fifties and she is the mother of four grown-up children who all work outsiD. the community. Felicia runs a small grocery store; she started her business two years ago. She would like to enlarge her store in order to increase her income and improve her financial conditions.

With her loan, she will buy goods that are running low in the store. Given the loan, she is sure she will be able to keep satisfying her customers and fulfill her dreams before long.

loans.use: Purchase of goods to replenish a small grocery store

texts.es:
Lidia is 38 years old and is married to Gustavo Alvarenga who is 39 years old. She has three children: two students and a one and a half year old baby.

For approximately three years, Lidia and her husband have dedicated themselves to the construction of rustic furniture, such as desks, long tables, and chairs. They not only make these items but also have their own store in front of their carpentry shop. Currently, they are making their products and exporting them to Germany. The credits that they previously withdrew from the Fundación were used to buy wood.

Today, they are soliciting a credit in order to buy more wood since they have received an order from a client for various tables and chairs.
 Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer. 




La Sra. Lidia tiene 38 años y está casada con el Sr. Gustavo Alvarenga que tiene 39 años con quien tienen 3 hijos, dos estudiantes y una beba de 1 año y medio.

Los mismos, desde hace aproximadamente 3 años, se dedican a la fabricación de muebles rústicos, como mesas, mesas largas, sillas, barcitos para sala y no solamente fabrican si no que también ya tienen su local de venta frente a su carpintería. 

En la actualidad están fabricando y exportando a Alemania  sus productos. Los créditos que retiró de la fundación lo utilizaron para la compra de madera.

Hoy solicita un crédito para comprar mas madera ya que ha recibido un pedido de varias mesas y sillas de un cliente.

loans.name: Virginia Conde Palomino's Group

texts.es:
Raquel, Virginia and Balvina have been partners of the Banco Comunal Santa Rita for 11, 10, and 7 years, respectively. Raquel tells us that she was a founder of the Banco Comunal and when she started she did so with a savings of two dollars. Through the Banco Comunal, they have learned how to be responsible, punctual and to save for the future. All of the partners of the Banco Comunal are good friends.

Raquel distributes food to the workers of the Kola Real Company. She also sells condiments from a small stall, located at an urban transport stop. Her dream is to open a small grocery store in her house.

Virginia has a small grocery store in her house; however, previously, she sold corn in the streets of Ayacucho. Meanwhile, Balvina has sold fruit in the Magdalena market for 17 years. Before, she sold food and vegetables but she stopped this business because it didn’t generate a lot of earnings.

Raquel, Virginia and Balvina need loans of 600 soles each, which will be invested in the purchase of eggs, cinnamon, oregano, cloves, garlic, beverages, cookies, sugar, rice, oil, soap, detergent, cumin, cocoa, salt, mangos, papayas, peaches, bananas and oranges. They will use their savings to build their houses and to increase their businesses’ capital. Raquel, Virginia and Balvina dream of equipping their businesses, building their houses, growing their businesses and that their children study to be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Raquel, Virginia y Balvina son socias del Banco Comunal Santa Rita hace 11, 10, 7 años respectivamente. Raquel nos cuenta que fue fundadora del Banco Comunal y que cuando se inició lo hizo con un ahorro D. 2 dólares. En el Banco Comunal dicen que han aprendido a ser responsables, puntuales y a ahorrar para el futuro y que todas las socias D. su Banco Comunal son muy amigas. Raquel reparte comida a los trabajadores D. la empresa Kola Real y también venD. condimentos en un pequeño puesto, ubicado en un paradero D. transporte urbano y su sueño es abrir una tienda D. abarrotes en su casa. Por otro lado Virginia tiene una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes en su casa, pero anteriormente ella vendía choclos en las calles D. Ayacucho. Mientras que Balvina venD. frutas en el mercado Magdalena desD. hace 17 años. Antes ella vendía comida y verduras pero dejó D. realizar dichos negocios porque no le generaban muchas ganancias. Raquel, Virginia y Balvina necesitan préstamos D. 600 soles cada una, que serán invertidos en la compra D. huevos, canela, orégano, clavo D. olor, ajos, refrescos, galletas, azúcar, arroz, aceite, jabón, detergente, comino, cocoa, sal, mango, papaya, durazno, plátano, naranja. Sus ahorros los utilizarán para construir su casa y para incrementar el capital D. su negocio. Los sueños D. Raquel, Virginia y Balvina son equipar su tienda, construir su casa, un negocio más granD. y que sus hijos estudien para que sean profesionales.

loans.use: Raquel, Virginia and Balvina need loans of 600 soles each, which will be invested in the purchase of eggs, cinnamon, oregano, cloves, garlic, beverages, cookies, sugar, rice, oil, soap, detergent, cumin, cocoa, salt, mangos, papayas, peaches, bananas and oranges.

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.es:
Cleyde is 38 years old and has two children, Elizabeth is also 38 years old and has one child, while Justina is 47 years old and has two children. Cleyde, Elizabeth and Justina have belonged to the Santa Rita Communal Bank for eight, six and seven years respectively. Members of their Communal Bank are close friends and they say that, whenever a member gets sick or has some need, they support one another morally and financially. They mention that they started saving at their Communal Bank, as it was impossible to do it at home. This is Cleyde’s case who, with her savings, managed to buy machinery for her business and a piece of land, and got married. Cleyde has a wood shop along with her husband, and she also runs a coffee shop at the Fine Arts School. On the other hand, Elizabeth has a sewing shop, where she makes women clothes. She was initially employed in a shop and, little by little, became independent and presently has all the necessary machinery. On her side, Justina has been selling food (potato and eggs) in the streets of downtown Ayacucho for the past 10 years.

Cleyde, Elizabeth and Justina are requesting a loan for soles 100, 800 and 600 respectively, which will be invested in the purchase of wood, plywood, glue, varnish, thinner, fabric, zippers, threads, knitting adhesive material, lace, elastic thread, potato and eggs. To expand the wood shop and buy all the needed machinery, to set up a store to sell and rent party gowns, and to register the property title of her land and see her children become professional are Cleyde’s, Elizabeth’s and Justina’s respective dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Cleyde tiene 38 años y 2 hijos, Elizabeth tiene 38 años y 1 hijo, mientras que Justina tiene 47 años y 2 hijos. Cleyde, Elizabeth y Justina pertenecen al Banco Comunal Santa Rita desde hace 8, 6, 7 años respectivamente. Las socias en su Banco Comunal son amigas y unidas y nos dicen que cuando hay socias que se enferman o tienen alguna necesidad ellas se apoyan moral y económicamente. Ellas mencionan que en su Banco Comunal comenzaron a ahorrar, porque en su casa era imposible ahorrar. Este es el caso de Cleyde, que con sus ahorros pudo comprar algunas maquinarias para su negocio, compró su terreno y también se casó. Cleyde, junto a su esposo, tiene un taller de carpintería y además ella tiene un cafetín en la escuela de Bellas Artes. Por otro lado, Elizabeth tiene su taller de confección de prendas de vestir para damas. Inicialmente Elizabeth trabajaba en un taller, y poco a poco fue independizándose y en la actualidad tiene todas las máquinas necesarias. Mientras que Justina vende papa con huevo sancochado y los vende en las calles del centro de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza hace 10 años.

Cleyde, Elizabeth y Justina necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 800 soles y 600 soles, que serán invertidos en la compra de madera, triplay, colas, laca, tiner, tela, cierre, hilos, pelón adhesivo, blondas, elásticos, papa, huevo. Los sueños de Cleyde, Elizabeth y Justina son ampliar su taller de carpintería y comprar todas sus máquinas, tener una tienda de venta y alquiler de vestidos de fiesta, hacer registrar el título de propiedad de su terreno y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Cleyde, Elizabeth and Justina are requesting a loan for soles 100, 800 and 600 respectively, which will be invested in the purchase of wood, plywood, glue, varnish, thinner, fabric, zippers, threads, knitting adhesive material, lace, elastic thread, potato and eggs.

loans.name: Groupement Des Agents De Santé Communautaire De Palmarin

texts.fr:
Palmarin is a village which has a little clinic which however does not have a nurse on duty. To deal with this problem and assure the health of the village people, a group of volunteers took a training course in order to work in the clinic at no charge to the village. To be able to do this, these women, joined together in a Group, are asking for a loan from SEM so that, outside the hours where they work in the clinic, they can take turns working in other money-earning ventures. This will prevent them from having to absent themselves from the clinic and thus allow for better health care for the villagers of Palmarin. Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteerLe village de Palmarin est un village qui abrite une case de santé et qui n'est pas dotté d'un infirmier.
Face a ce problème, et pour la sécurisation des villageois, de bonnes volontés ayant subit une formation afin de pouvoir s'occupées de la santé des populations et sans aucun revenu.
Pour ce faire, ces agents réunis en Groupemet sollicite un prêt à SEM afin de pouvoir en dehors des heures de services dans la case de santé  travailler a tour de rôle dans d'autres activités génératrice de revenus leurs permettant d'éviter d'éventuels absence pour une meilleure prise en charge de la santé des populations de Palmarin.

loans.use: Purchase and re-sale of diverse goods (fruits and vegetables)Achat et vente de marchandise divers( Fruits et légumes)

texts.en: Anvar B. lives in Beylagan, a small city in the southwestern region of Azerbaijan. He is 50 years old, married and has five children. He rented a food market in Beylagan. Anvar sells sweets, sugar, drinks, and sausages, among other goods, at his market. His son helps him in selling. Anvar needs a loan in the amount of $1,200 to expand his business.

Hanifa B. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 57 years old, married and has five children. Hanifa sells fruits and vegetables with his wife at the Beylagan city bazaar. He started his business ten years ago. Hanifa needs a loan in the amount of $500 to buy more kinds of goods so he can expand his business.

Zohrab H. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 48 years old, married and has three children. He has been driving a taxi for a few years. He needs a loan in amount of $600 so that he can repair his car.

Minaya M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. She is 42 years old, married and has three children. She is selling women shoes in Beylagan city bazaar. Her youngest son (pictured) helps her at her job. She started her business five years ago. Minaya needs a loan in amount of $700 to buy more kind of shoes and expand her business.

Tamella M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. She is 57 years old, married and has five children. She sells women's clothes in the Beylagan city bazaar. Her husband helps her at her job. She has fifteen years experience in this business. Tamella needs a loan in the amount of $1,200 to buy more kinds of clothes so she can expand her business.

loans.name: Aurora Maria's Group

texts.es:
Fermina, Aurora and Cristina have belonged to the Wood Communal Bank for 1, 3, and 1 years respectively. In their Communal Bank they learned about how to prevent illnesses, attend clients, invest and save.

Fermina is 40 years old, has 2 children and has sold slippers for 8 years. At first her merchandise was minimal. Recently her business has grown. She sells her slippers in the markets of Seccelambras and Quinua and in the Chorro Market. Aurora, on the other hand, is 37 years old and has 5 children. Aurora has been selling vegetables and fruits in the markets of Pampamarca and Seccelambras for 9 years. She brings wheat, barley, quinua (a Peruvian grain used to make pasta), and corn to the markets and sells them to the mills. Cristina is 56 years old and has 8 children. She sells typical foods such as spicy puca and tripe in the market of Nazarenas.

The loans of Fermina, Aurora and Cristina are of 600 soles, 400 soles and 400 soles respectively. The loans will be used to purchase slippers, carrots, onions, sugar, rice, noodles, soap, chickpeas, pallar beans, potatoes, and corn. Their savings will be used in the construction of their house, to buy bricks and for emergencies. The dreams of Fermina, Aurora and Cristina are as different as having a shoe store, building a house, starting a new business, buying a stall in the market and helping their children to be professionals.

translated from Spanish by B, Kiva volunteer

Fermina, Aurora y Cristina pertenecen al Banco Comunal Torcaza hace 1, 3, 1 años respectivamente, en su Banco Comunal las capacitaron acerca D. cómo prevenir las enfermedades, cómo atender a los clientes, cómo invertir y aprendieron a ahorrar.

Fermina tiene 40 años y 2 hijos y desD. hace 8 años venD. zapatillas. Al inicio su mercadería era mínima, en la actualidad su negocio ha crecido, sus ventas las realiza en las ferias D. Seccelambras, Quinua y en el Mercado Chorro. Por otro lado Aurora tiene 37 años y 5 hijos, Aurora es feriante hace 9 años, venD. verduras y frutas en las ferias D. Pampamarca y Seccelambras, y D. las ferias trae trigo, cebada, quinua, maíz y los venD. en los molinos. Mientras que Cristina tiene 56 años y 8 hijos y venD. comida típica como puca picante y mondongo en la feria D. Nazarenas.

Los préstamos D. Fermina, Aurora y Cristina son D. 600 soles, 400 soles y 400 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra D. zapatillas, zanahorias, cebolla, azúcar, arroz, fideo, jabón, garbanzo, pallar, papa, maíz. Sus ahorros los utilizarán en la construcción D. su casa, para comprar ladrillo y para alguna emergencia. Los sueños D. Fermina, Aurora y Cristina son diferentes como tener una tienda D. zapatos, construir su casa, implementar un nuevo negocio, comprar un puesto en el mercado y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: To purchase slippers, carrots, onions, sugar, rice, noodles, soap, chickpeas, pallar beans, potatoes, and corn.

texts.en: Dilara N. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. She is 45 years old, married and has three children. She is selling women clothes in Beylagan city bazaar. She has seven years experience at this business. Dilara needs a loan of $1200 to buy more kinds of clothes and expand her business.

loans.name: Rosa's Group

texts.es:
Elvira, Rose and Rosalinda have been associates of the Paradise Communal Bank for 11, 3, 1 year respectively. In their Communal Bank they say that they learned to save and to be more organized, generous, responsible, and punctual.

Elvira is 53 years old and has 2 children. Elvira offers her services as a scribe, creating different documents in a central street of Ayacucho. She has worked doing this for 20 years.

On the other hand, Rose is 50 years old and has 3 children. Rose started selling clothes to order three years ago. She brings her merchandise to Lima and at times to Tacna. Previously she had a grocery store, but she closed it because of low sales.

Rosalinda is 24 years old and has 1 son. Her business is making pretty costume jewelry, like pins, earrings, and rings. She learned to make the jewelry in Lima when she worked with her cousins. Besides the costume jewelry, she sells clothes to order.

Elvira, Rose and Rosalinda need loans of 600 soles, 800 soles and 600 soles, respectively, that will be invested in the purchase of papers, beads of various sizes, handles, hoops, imported stones, polos, jeans, sweaters, and blouses.
